• The @xmath0 ncsm / rgm approach, initially presented as a method to treat both structure and reactions in light nuclear systems, combines a microscopic cluster technique with realistic interactions and a consistent description of nucleon clusters.

• This method, initially detailed for two-body cluster bases, has been shown to work efficiently in various systems. However, it faces limitations when studying systems with a three-body cluster structure, which cannot be successfully analyzed with a two-body cluster approach.

• The extension of the ncsm / rgm approach to properly describe three-body cluster states is crucial for studying nuclear systems with such configurations. This is particularly relevant for systems like two-nucleon halo nuclei, resonant systems, and transfer reactions with three fragments in their final states.

• Recently, the method has been adapted to include three-body cluster configurations, and initial results have been presented for the @xmath1he ground state. The extension requires expanding the many-body wave function over a basis of three-body cluster channel states built from the ncsm wave function of each of the three clusters.

• The formalism involves solving the Schrödinger equations by orthogonalizing them and transforming to the hyperspherical harmonics (hh) basis, resulting in a set of non-local integral-differential equations. These equations are then solved using the microscopic r-matrix method on a Lagrange mesh.

• The developed formalism has been applied to study the @xmath1he nucleus, focusing on its ground state and continuum states within a @xmath2he+n+n cluster basis. The results show that the wave functions obtained within this approach feature an appropriate asymptotic behavior, differing from those obtained using bound-state methods like the ncsm.

* The document discusses the successful growth of MnGe thin films on silicon substrates using a MnSi seed layer, which allows for the adoption of the b20 crystal structure of MnGe. The films exhibit a variety of interesting magnetic phases, offering potential for applications in future spintronic devices.
* The magnetic characterization of the MnGe films reveals an ordering temperature of 200K, an enhancement compared to bulk material, and a behavior typical for antiferromagnetic order, attributed to the shorter and more rigid helix structure in MnGe compared to MnSi, which is related to a stronger Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya interaction.

• The document discusses the concept of core entropy in the context of quadratic polynomials, focusing on the Hubbard tree and its role in defining the core entropy. It introduces the notion of a labeled wedge and its associated graph to compute the core entropy for any angle, not just rational ones.

• The core entropy function is shown to extend continuously from the Mandelbrot set to the entire complex plane, answering a question posed by W. Thurston. This continuity is proven by developing an algorithm that leverages the properties of labeled wedges and their associated graphs.

• The paper also explores the relationship between the core entropy and other geometric and dynamical properties, such as the Hausdorff dimension of the set of biaccessible angles and the asymptotic stretch factor of the polynomial as a rational map. It discusses the growth rate of countable graphs with bounded cycles and the spectral determinant as a tool to study these graphs.

• The document contributes to the understanding of the core entropy by providing a combinatorial method to compute it for any angle, not just rational ones, and by proving the continuity of the core entropy function. It also connects the core entropy to other mathematical concepts like dynamical zeta functions and thermodynamic formalism, highlighting its rich structure and its role in the study of complex dynamics.

* The detection of x-ray, optical, and radio afterglows from some well-localized gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) indicates that at least most long GRBs are of cosmological origin, supporting the fireball model. However, determining the degree of collimation in GRBs remains a significant challenge.
* The issue of whether GRBs are due to highly collimated jets or isotropic fireballs is unresolved, affecting the determination of the energetics involved. Analyzing optical afterglows, polarization, and orphan afterglows are methods used to determine the collimation, but each has limitations and complexities.
* The presence of "failed gamma-ray bursts" (FGRBs), or baryon-contaminated fireballs with initial Lorentz factors much less than 1000 but still greater than unity, complicates the understanding of GRB origins. FGRBs can produce orphan afterglows, which should be considered when interpreting orphan afterglow observations.

• Gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) are mysterious events in the universe, typically lasting less than a minute, but they produce X-ray afterglows that can be detected for several hours to days.

• Since the first discovery of GRBs in 1997, it has been known that these bursts also produce X-ray afterglows, which can be detected with modern X-ray observatories.

• Over the last five years, several X-ray afterglows have been observed by satellites such as BeppoSAX, ASCA, Chandra, XMM-Newton, and RXTE.

• This letter reports on two X-ray afterglow observations made with XMM-Newton.

• GRB 011211 was detected and localized on December 11, 2001, with its distinguishing features being its long duration and faintness in X-rays.

• An optical afterglow of GRB 011211 was discovered, and its spectrum was found to correspond to a redshift of z=2.14.

• GRB 001025 was detected by RXTE on October 25, 2000, and its X-ray afterglow was observed by XMM-Newton.

• The X-ray light curve of GRB 011211 afterglow can be fit with a power-law function, and its X-ray flux was found to decline during the observation.

• The X-ray spectrum of the afterglow of GRB 001025 was typical of X-ray afterglows of GRBs, supporting its identification as such.

• The X-ray spectra of the afterglows did not show significant absorption above galactic values, which is consistent with the lack of detected reddening in the optical afterglow spectrum.

• The text discusses the study of the layered organic material AI3, which has attracted renewed interest due to the discovery of low-energy massless Dirac fermions under hydrostatic pressure.

• AI3 differs from graphene and topological insulators in terms of the tilt of Dirac cones, anisotropy in the Fermi surface, and the average Fermi velocity, which is roughly an order of magnitude smaller.

• The presence of a low-temperature charge-ordered phase at ambient pressure indicates the relevance of electronic correlations in AI3.

• The effective coupling constant for Coulomb-type electron-electron interactions is expected to be ten times larger in AI3 than in graphene due to the inverse proportionality to the Fermi velocity.

• AI3 presents an exciting prospect for studying strongly-correlated Dirac fermions beyond the scope of graphene electrons.

• The material also features additional massive carriers near the Fermi level, as identified in ab-initio band-structure calculations.

• The interplay between massless Dirac fermions and massive carriers has not yet been proven experimentally.

• Magneto-transport measurements under hydrostatic pressure reveal the existence of high-mobility Dirac carriers and low-mobility massive holes, in agreement with recent band-structure calculations.

* The text discusses the analysis of spin response in Fe-based superconductors (FeBS) with two different superconducting gap scales, focusing on the role of the indirect gap in determining the true spin resonance.
* Spin resonance appears in the unconventional superconducting state below the indirect gap scale, which is determined by the sum of gaps on two Fermi surface sheets connected by the scattering wave vector.
* For most FeBS materials, the indirect gap is either 4 or 5, providing a simple criterion to identify the true spin resonance from inelastic neutron scattering data.
* If one of the gaps is 0, there are three possible scenarios regarding the peak frequency and gap structure, with the definitive conclusion requiring calculation of the dynamical spin susceptibility for the specific experimental band structure.
* The text compares energy scales extracted from various experimental techniques, such as ARPES, Andreev spectroscopy, and inelastic neutron scattering, to determine the superconducting gap structure.
* It notes discrepancies between gap sizes extracted from ARPES and Andreev spectroscopy in some materials, suggesting that one method may overestimate or underestimate the superconducting gaps.
* The text also discusses the appearance of a hump structure in the superconducting state, which may be related to the 128 energy scale, and its origin in relation to spin-orbit coupling or pre-existing magnon modes.
* Finally, the text acknowledges the importance of future experiments to fill gaps in available data and provides conclusions based on the analysis of peak frequency and gap sizes in specific FeBS materials.

* The presence of impurities significantly alters the spectrum, coherence, and transport properties of quantum systems.
* In the absence of interactions, if impurities are randomly distributed, states are exponentially localized in 1D and 2D, while a mobility edge exists in 3D.
* Correlated disorder, such as minimum distances between impurities, can introduce delocalized states in the spectrum.
* The random dimer model (RDM) and dual random dimer model (DRDM) demonstrate this in 1D, while its effects in 2D are less explored.
* In 2D, correlations in speckle potentials can mimic a mobility edge, but all states are localized in the thermodynamic limit.
* Random dimers in pseudo-2D lattices introduce delocalized states similar to 1D, differing in the decay of the correlation function.
* In interacting systems, disordered impurities lead to a rich variety of phenomena, including modified condensate and superfluid properties.
* This work studies the effect of short-range correlated disorder on a Bose gas confined on a 2D square lattice.
* A 2D-DRDM model is introduced, showing that in the non-interacting regime, a resonance energy exists where the structured impurity is transparent, leading to delocalized states.
* Considering weakly interacting Bose gases, the 2D-DRDM drives the homogeneity of the ground state, inducing a non-monotonic behavior of the condensate spatial delocalization and fraction.
* The dependence of these quantities on interaction strength is explained by including the effect of the healing length in the resonance condition discussion.
* The manuscript explores the 2D-DRDM potential's impact on a weakly interacting Bose gas, comparing it to an uncorrelated random disorder, and discusses the density distribution and condensate fraction as functions of disorder strength.

* The document discusses the maximum independent set problem for generalized Petersen graphs, focusing on finding upper and lower bounds for the independence number. It introduces a new upper bound for the independence number when the parameter is even, compares it with existing bounds, and provides exact values for some cases. The paper also presents lower bounds for the independence number when the parameter is even and includes a section on exact values for certain pairs of parameters. Additionally, it proves Behsaz-Hatami-Mahmoodian's conjecture for some cases using known lower bounds.
* The text outlines an upper bound for the independence number of generalized Petersen graphs when the parameter is even, which is better than the bound given by Behsaz et al. It also describes a construction for an independent set in these graphs and establishes lower bounds for the independence number when the parameter is even. The paper further provides exact values for the independence number for some pairs of parameters and proves Behsaz-Hatami-Mahmoodian's conjecture for certain cases. It concludes with a section on finding the independence number of generalized Petersen graphs with fixed parameters in linear time, using dynamic programming techniques on graphs with bounded treewidth.

• The text discusses quantum key distribution (QKD) methods, specifically focusing on quantum key distribution using measurement-device-independent (MDI) protocols.

• MDI-QKD allows for secure key generation without detailed knowledge of the devices used, enhancing security against potential vulnerabilities.

• The text introduces the concept of device-independent security proofs, which theoretically ensure security but may not apply to practical QKD systems due to testing limitations.

• Practical attacks on QKD systems have been proposed and demonstrated, leading to the development of countermeasures like device-independent security proofs.

• The text proposes a Measurement Device Independent Quantum Key Distribution (MDIQKD) scheme that uses a measurement unit (MU) to establish quantum correlations between Alice and Bob, without requiring detailed device knowledge.

• The MDIQKD scheme is based on a reversed EPR-based QKD protocol, which is equivalent to EPR-based QKD in terms of security but removes potential loopholes related to detector imperfections.

• The scheme is shown to be secure against practical attacks, with the only assumption being the perfect preparation of quantum signal sources by Alice and Bob.

• Imperfections in quantum signal sources, particularly basis-dependent flaws, are discussed as a critical issue for the practical implementation of MDIQKD.

• The text also addresses the challenges of implementing MDIQKD with phase encoding, considering the time-dependent birefringence effects in optical fibers, and proposes solutions to enhance the scheme's performance and security.

• The formation process of massive stars remains enigmatic due to the difficulty in isolating individual protostars for study, caused by their clustered mode of formation and large distances to the nearest examples.

• Recent observations at wavelengths less affected by obscuring material have revealed environments surrounding individual massive protostellar systems, suggesting an accretion formation scenario for massive stars.

• High resolution observations of hot molecular cores, which exclusively trace regions of massive star formation, can further discriminate between accretion and merger models of massive star formation.

• Mid-infrared (MIR) observations provide a powerful view of these regions, as the large column densities of material process stellar light to infrared wavelengths, allowing for diffraction-limited observations.

• Methanol masers, found closest to the brightest MIR point source, indicate that they are associated with massive star formation, supporting the accretion formation scenario.

• Monte Carlo simulations suggest that it is difficult to generate the observed mass distributions of the most massive stars from the available gas mass using a standard form of the initial mass function, indicating a potential bias towards high-mass star formation.

• Modified theories of gravity, particularly focusing on Lovelock theory and its generalizations, have gained significant attention due to the discovery of an accelerating universe, attributed to a mysterious force known as dark energy. These theories aim to explore the characteristics of dark energy by modifying Einstein's theory of general relativity.

• The Lovelock theory of gravity, a direct generalization of general relativity, introduces additional curvature invariants in higher dimensions. The Ricci scalar and the Gauss-Bonnet (GB) invariant are key components, with the GB invariant being particularly interesting due to its topological nature and its ability to avoid spin-2 ghost instabilities. GB gravity in 4 dimensions can be coupled with scalar fields or generic functions in the Einstein-Hilbert action, leading to alternative explanations for dark energy.

• Modified gravity theories, including those based on Lovelock theory, are used to reconstruct various cosmological models such as de Sitter universes, power-law solutions, and models with phantom or non-phantom eras. These models are analyzed for stability against linear perturbations, providing insights into the dynamics of the universe's expansion. Theories are also applied to discuss the cosmic evolution of the universe, including the role of dark matter and dark energy, and their compatibility with observational data.

* Majorana fermions (MFs) are real solutions of the Dirac equation and their own antiparticles, originally proposed for modeling neutrinos but recently predicted to occur in engineered condensed matter systems.
* MFs exhibit non-abelian statistics, crucial for potential applications in decoherence-free quantum computation and quantum information processing.
* Various platforms, including topological superconductors, semiconductor nanowires, and atomic chains, have been proposed to support MFs based on the superconducting proximity effect.
* Experimentally observing unique MF signatures, such as characteristic zero-bias peaks (ZBPs), remains a significant challenge due to potential confounding mechanisms.
* An optical scheme is proposed to detect MFs in iron chains on a superconducting Pb surface using a coupled hybrid quantum dot (QD)-nanomechanical resonator (NR) system.
* The interaction between MFs and the QD-NR system is primarily through dipole-dipole interaction, allowing for adjustable distance without direct contact, thus avoiding interference from other signals.
* The coherent optical spectrum of the QD, influenced by the MFs, serves as a potential signature for MFs, offering an alternative to tunnel spectroscopy.
* The NR's vibration enhances the exciton resonance spectrum, making MFs more sensitive to detection, providing a new platform for robust manipulation and quantum information processing based on MFs.
* The proposed optical scheme offers a distinct method for detecting MFs, complementing existing tunnel spectroscopy techniques, and potentially enabling all-optical controlled topological quantum computing.

* The document discusses the violation of time reversal symmetry in the kaon system, focusing on the search for physics beyond the standard model of elementary particles. It explores various theoretical models and their implications for time reversal symmetry, including dynamical symmetry breaking, multi-Higgs models, spontaneous symmetry breaking, grand unified theories, extended gauge groups, and supersymmetric theories. The text also addresses the challenges in relating quark degrees of freedom to hadronic degrees of freedom due to the absence of a complete solution for quantum chromodynamics at relevant energies.
* The paper aims to estimate hadronic matrix elements that arise when relating quark operators to effective hadronic parameterizations of time reversal symmetry violation. It outlines the charge exchange and axial vector type exchange nucleon-nucleon interactions, discusses the calculation of matrix elements from quark structure, and presents results for different types of quark models. The document also highlights the importance of experimental precision tests in constraining theoretical models and the role of quark models in describing low-energy sectors.

• Type IA supernovae (SNe Ia) are characterized by their strong Si lines in spectra and are brighter than other supernovae, making them useful as standard candles for measuring distances to remote galaxies.
• A plausible explosion model for SNe Ia is the accreting white dwarf (WD) model, where a white dwarf in a binary system accretes material from a companion star, increasing its mass to the Chandrasekhar limit, and then explodes.
• The accreting WD model has two main evolutionary paths leading to SNe Ia: the super soft X-ray source (SSS) channel and the symbiotic channel.
• Observations have not confirmed the evolutionary scenario for SNe Ia, requiring the identification of the companion star that remains near the explosion site.
• A method to prove the companion star is located inside the supernova ejecta involves observing very broad wings in absorption lines of iron (Fe) in the spectrum, which are likely formed by Fe in the ejecta.
• The companion star's absorption lines with only a blue wing can be identified, indicating the star is inside the supernova ejecta.
• The amount of Fe in the ejecta of Tycho's supernova remnant (SNR) can be estimated, and spectra of a star located at the center of a SNR can be discussed to identify the Fe absorption line features.
• Factors that might reduce or erase distinct absorption features include uncertainties in the explosion model, such as the number of ionizing photons and the ionization stages of ions in the shocked region.

• The text discusses quantum entanglement, focusing on its role in quantum information processing and its characterization as a physical resource. It introduces the entropy of entanglement as a measure for pure states and discusses the challenges in quantifying entanglement for mixed states.

• It introduces the concepts of entanglement of formation and entanglement of distillation, which are measures that satisfy the requirements for a physical entanglement measure. These measures are used to address the problem of quantifying entanglement in mixed states, particularly in the context of open quantum systems.

• The text presents a method using quantum trajectory theory to analyze the dynamics of entanglement in open quantum systems, particularly in the case of cascaded qubit systems. It demonstrates that the entanglement dynamics can exhibit bimodality and the existence of entangled-state cycles, which are distinct behaviors that emerge from the interaction between the system and its environment.

• The paper also explores the implications of entanglement in the context of open systems and the role of measurements on the environment in unraveling the density operator and creating entanglement. It highlights the importance of considering the process through which a mixed state is generated and the potential access to conditional dynamics when analyzing entanglement in open quantum systems.

* The difference between Type 1 and Type 2 Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) is explained by angle-dependent circumnuclear obscuration of the accretion disk and broad-line region, with the obscuring dusty medium commonly referred to as a "dust torus."
* The dust torus is optically and geometrically thick, extending from sub-parsec scales outward to several tens of parsecs, or beyond for high-luminosity objects. It absorbs incident UV/optical radiation and re-emits the received energy in the infrared.
* Type 1 AGN show significantly more emission in the near-infrared than Type 2 AGN for the same intrinsic luminosity, consistent with the face-on view onto the torus exposing the innermost hot dust to the observer, while Type 2 AGN have internal obscuration blocking the line-of-sight to the hot dust.
* The isotropic selection of the sample helps minimize biasing effects on the anisotropy, but optically- and x-ray-selected samples often miss some of the most obscured objects. Flux-limited mid-infrared selected samples are potentially biased towards Type 1 AGN.
* The clumpy torus models reproduce the observed Type 1/Type 2 AGN anisotropy reasonably well over most of the wavelength range, suggesting the observed anisotropy is a measure for the intrinsic anisotropy of luminous Type 1 and Type 2 AGN.

* The text discusses the impact of local oscillator (LO) intensity fluctuation on continuous-variable quantum key distribution (CVQKD) systems, particularly in relation to Eve's potential attacks and the security of the shared secret keys between Alice and Bob.
* It highlights that without proper monitoring of LO intensity, Eve can exploit fluctuations to reduce channel transmission and excess noise, leading to underestimation of her intercepted information and potential theft of secret keys.
* The paper presents a theoretical analysis and numerical simulations showing that LO intensity fluctuations can significantly compromise the security of CVQKD, especially over long distances or with low channel transmissions.
* It emphasizes the necessity of monitoring LO intensity and scaling measurements with instantaneous intensity values to ensure the unconditional security of the shared secret keys in practical CVQKD implementations.

• The development aimed to create a simple and efficient tool for computing adiabatic oscillation frequencies and eigenfunctions for general stellar models, emphasizing accuracy. The code offers flexibility in integration methods and the ability to determine all frequencies within a given model range.

• The equilibrium model is defined using a minimal set of dimensionless variables, including distance to the center, mass interior to that point, photospheric radius, and mass. The code provides extensive documentation and is based on works by @xcite, which reviewed adiabatic stellar oscillations and discussed the Aarhus package.

• The code defines the dimensionless characteristic frequencies, such as the buoyancy frequency, Lamb frequency, and acoustic cut-off frequency, in terms of the adiabatic sound speed, pressure scale height, and gravitational acceleration. It also calculates the squared sound speed and dimensionless frequencies.

• The code uses spherical harmonic functions to represent the displacement vector of nonradial modes, with associated Legendre functions and normalization constants. It introduces dimensionless variables for the perturbation to the gravitational potential and density, and solves the equations of adiabatic stellar oscillations using these variables. The code also discusses the numerical treatment of boundary conditions and the use of different integration techniques.

• The document discusses the manifestation of high-structured HI distribution in gas-rich galaxies, characterized by cavities, shells, and supershells.

• These features, first discovered in the Milky Way, are now known to exist in several spiral galaxies, including edge-on spirals like NGC 5775, NGC 4631, NGC 3044, and NGC 3556.

• Supershells in these galaxies are interpreted as expanding structures due to their loop-like or circular appearance in projection and their wide velocity range or evidence of expansion in position-velocity space.

• Two main classes of explanations for the supershells posit their kinetic energy source to be either internal (starbursts, stellar winds, and supernova explosions) or external (infall of massive gas clouds).

• The internal source model involves starbursts, driving stellar winds and subsequent supernova explosions, which are linked to correlations between HI shells and other halo gas and star formation processes.

• The chimney model attempts to explain disk-halo features and other halo gas via processes related to underlying star formation, suggesting that HI supershells might be responsible for the presence of HI in the halo.

• The external source hypothesis invokes infall of massive gas clouds onto the galactic plane due to gravitational interaction with neighboring galaxies, resolving the energy problem since input energy is a function of the mass and velocity of the infalling cloud.

• The document proposes a new explanation for HI supershells, suggesting they have been formed by radio jets that plow through the interstellar medium, accreting ISM gas and sometimes inflating bubbles. This allows for an internal energy source for the HI shells, provides a natural explanation for any spatial symmetries seen in the HI features, and resolves the energy problem.

* The text discusses the first color-magnitude diagrams (CMDs) of the dwarf spheroidal (dSph) companions of the Milky Way, particularly Draco, which showed features similar to globular clusters.
* The presence of RR Lyrae stars in dSph galaxies, like Draco, led to the interpretation that they are essentially pure population II systems.
* However, Baade noted differences between dSph galaxies and globular clusters, including extreme red horizontal branches and distinct variable stars.
* The discovery of carbon stars in dSph galaxies revealed the presence of an intermediate-age population.
* CMDs of several dSph galaxies, including Carina, Fornax, Leo I, and Leo II, have shown a dominant old stellar population.
* Leo I is unique among dSph galaxies due to its well-populated red clump but no evident horizontal branch, suggesting delayed first substantial star formation.
* Leo I's large galactocentric radial velocity suggests it may not be bound to the Milky Way, unlike other dSph galaxies.
* The paper presents new HST F555W and F814W observations of Leo I, aiming to study its stellar populations and metallicity.
* Previous work on Leo I has indicated a large quantity of intermediate-age stars, with a prominent red clump and no evident horizontal branch.
* The CMD of Leo I, extending about 2 magnitudes deeper than previous photometry, shows a broad range in ages, with a continuous star formation history.
* The paper discusses the photometric errors and calibration, using artificial star tests to assess the total errors in the photometry.
* The CMD of Leo I is compared with theoretical isochrones to understand its stellar populations, indicating a range of ages from 10^15 years to less than 1 year.
* The paper concludes that Leo I has a unique stellar population among Local Group galaxies, with a young age range and a continuous star formation history.

• The article is motivated by Berestycki et al.'s result on the Laplacian perturbed by a divergence-free drift in dimensions.
• The study focuses on a bounded, regular open set and a bounded vector field with zero divergence in the sense of distributions.
• The principal eigen-pair corresponding to the Dirichlet problem for the operator is discussed.
• Theorem 0.3 asserts that the operator remains bounded as the parameter approaches infinity if and only if the equation has a solution, called a first integral, that satisfies certain conditions.
• The existence of non-trivial first integrals allows for flow lines contained in the set, while the absence of such integrals results in the flow leaving the set with speed proportional to the vector field.
• The addition of the Laplacian or Brownian motion changes the stochastic process's trajectories, but the general picture remains similar.
• The main difficulty in the development is the roughness of general elements of the Sobolev space and the non-locality of the fractional Laplacian, which prevent a direct application of differential calculus.
• Bogdan and Dyda's paper, Díperna and Lions' approximation techniques, and properties of the Green function and heat kernel of gradient perturbations of the fractional Laplacian are used to define and study the principal eigen-pair.
• The main result states that if the domain is simply connected and the fractional Laplacian parameter is greater than the dimension, the principal eigenvalue remains bounded as the parameter approaches infinity, with the infimum being attained.

• The text discusses the inference of macroscopic properties from microscopic descriptions in various physics disciplines, focusing on phase transitions and symmetry breaking.

• Phase transitions are characterized by drastic changes in macroscopic properties, often involving symmetry breaking, and are typically identified by an order parameter.

• Landau's phenomenological model and the renormalization group have been used to formulate theories of phase transitions, with order parameters being crucial for their identification.

• For some states of matter, like topological insulators, quantum spin hall states, and quantum spin liquids, defining an order parameter can be complex and non-local.

• Machine learning, particularly neural networks, is proposed as a new method to identify parameters for phase transitions, potentially offering insights into systems where traditional methods are insufficient.

• Neural networks, especially variational autoencoders, are highlighted for their ability to approximate functions and find structure in data, making them suitable for unsupervised learning tasks.

• The text demonstrates the application of variational autoencoders to the Ising model and the XY model, successfully identifying phase transitions without prior knowledge of the microscopic theory or order parameters.

• The reconstruction error from the autoencoder is suggested as a universal indicator for phase transitions, offering a practical tool for physicists to predict unseen phases or uncover unknown order parameters.

* The source document discusses the quantum cloning machine (QCM) and its inability to perfectly clone quantum states due to the laws of quantum mechanics.
* QCMs can produce identical (symmetric), non-identical (non-symmetric), or state-dependent (universal) copies of quantum states.
* QCMs are designed based on specific conditions and can be used for various applications, including quantum cryptography and quantum informatics.
* One application is quantum eavesdropping, where QCMs are designed to copy specific parts of quantum states.
* The document focuses on "partial" QCMs that clone one constituent of two-partite states, considering both pure and mixed states.
* Any mixed state can be seen as a reduced form of a pure state, known as "purification," which influences the cloning process.
* The document provides a detailed description of constructing a QCM for two-partite qubit states, including the definition of the unitary operator and the choice of parameters.
* The fidelity measure is used to assess the quality of cloning, with a focus on state-dependent QCMs that show improved cloning quality due to their design.
* The document also discusses the cloning of mixed qubit states, emphasizing the use of purification and the construction of "partial" QCMs for this purpose.
* The choice of parameters for QCMs is based on minimizing the "distance" between the initial and output states, leading to improved cloning quality for state-dependent QCMs.

* The nature of dark matter remains an outstanding question in modern astrophysics.
* The success of the cold dark matter cosmological model argues for a major component of dark matter being an elementary particle.
* The inventory of baryons locally falls short of the total inferred from cosmic microwave background fluctuations, leaving open the possibility of a significant baryonic component of dark matter.
* Models including a large component of baryonic dark matter have been proposed, particularly involving dense gas clouds.
* Dense gas clouds are predicted to emit gamma rays from cosmic ray interactions, potentially yielding a diffuse flux comparable to known sources.
* The EGRET detector's high-quality data on diffuse emission can be used to constrain dark matter models.
* Previous investigations have neglected self-shielding and cascade phenomena at high column densities, employing emissivities appropriate to low-density limits.
* The gamma-ray spectra from cosmic ray interactions with dense gas clouds have been calculated using a Monte Carlo simulation code.
* The predicted spectra differ substantially between high and low column-density clouds, with gamma-ray emission dominated by specific processes at different densities.
* The constraints on the baryonic content of the galaxy's dark halo are less stringent than previously thought due to the low emissivity of dense gas.

* The text discusses the development of novel materials through self-assembly of colloidal suspensions, with a particular focus on colloidal crystals. These crystals can generate iridescent colors and are relevant for photonic crystals, lasers, display devices, and other applications. The text also highlights the importance of colloidal crystals in studying thermodynamics and condensed matter physics.
* The ability to tune the interactions between colloidal particles, especially through the application of electric fields, has led to the observation of various structures, including anisotropic interparticle potentials and exotic crystal structures. These structures are not typically found in atomic and molecular systems. The text also mentions the use of rotating electric fields to induce dipolar interactions, leading to anisotropic crystal structures and direct observation of phase transitions.
* The text presents a method for modeling the behavior of colloidal crystals using Monte Carlo simulations. It involves combining electrostatic repulsions and dipolar attractions to predict the lattice spacing in quasi-2D colloidal crystals. The simulations are compared with experimental results, and the text discusses the effects of varying parameters such as particle size, ionic strength, and electric field strength on the lattice spacing. The text also explores the tunability of the lattice spacing for different particle sizes and suggests that intermediate particle sizes may have the highest degree of tunability for display applications.

* The source document discusses the properties of soft X-ray transients (SXRTs), particularly focusing on Aql X-1, which is the most active SXRT known. It highlights the similarities between SXRTs and persistent low-mass X-ray binaries (LMXBs) containing neutron stars, and the differences in their outburst characteristics.
* Aql X-1's outbursts are characterized by a fast rise followed by a slow decay, with type I X-ray bursts observed during the declining phase, indicating the presence of a neutron star. The X-ray luminosities are in the range of 10^36-10^38 erg/s, and the spectrum changes from soft to power-law during the outburst decay.
* The document analyzes the X-ray spectra of Aql X-1 during its outburst decay and in quiescence, finding a soft black body component in quiescence with a radius decreasing by a factor of 10 compared to the decay phase. The power law component changes substantially, hardening in quiescence, and the ratio of the 0.5-10 keV luminosities in the power law and black body components decreases by a factor of five.
* The document explores the possibility of a millisecond radio pulsar (MSP) turning on in the quiescent state of SXRTs, providing a missing link between persistent LMXBs and recycled MSPs. It discusses the outburst decay of Aql X-1, noting the sharp flux decay leading to the quiescent state, and the transition to the propeller regime, where most of the inflowing matter is stopped at the magnetospheric boundary. The document also examines the neutron star's magnetic field and spin, suggesting a neutron star magnetic field of 10^8-10^9 G based on the observed luminosity ratio.

• The text discusses the discovery and analysis of supernova 2006jc, a possible Type Ib supernova, and its association with a luminous blue variable (LBV) event.

• The supernova was discovered on October 9, 2006, by @xcite, who also reported an optical transient in 2004 close to the supernova's position, suggesting a possible connection.

• Follow-up observations in various wavebands, including X-ray, UV, optical, infrared, and radio, were conducted to study the supernova's properties and its interaction with the circumstellar medium (CSM).

• Spectroscopic observations revealed broad features and strong narrow emission lines, leading to the classification of the supernova as Type Ib.

• The supernova showed unusual spectral features, such as a bright blue continuum in the early stages, which is not typical for standard supernovae.

• Photometric observations showed a rapid decline in optical light and an increase in near-infrared (NIR) emissions, suggesting ongoing dust formation.

• X-ray and UV emissions were detected, indicating an interaction between the supernova ejecta and the CSM. However, radio emissions were not detected.

• A theoretical model was presented, suggesting the supernova explosion was from a Wolf-Rayet (WR) star, with a focus on the progenitor's properties and the dust formation process.

• The model explains the supernova's bolometric luminosity, X-ray emission, and the observed light curve, attributing the energy source to the decay of radioactive isotopes.

• The model also discusses the connection between the supernova and a possible LBV event that occurred two years before the explosion, although the mechanism of the outburst remains unclear.

• The study concludes with a summary of the model's key findings, including the progenitor's properties, the explosion mechanism, and the implications for the supernova's energy source and dust formation.

• The text discusses the extreme variability and multi-wavelength correlation in the micro-quasar GRS 1915+105, which is attributed to its high accretion rate close to or exceeding the Eddington limit. It also highlights the unique variability patterns observed in the newly discovered X-ray transient source IGR J170913624, which are similar to those in GRS 1915+105, suggesting a generic phenomenon of extreme variability in black hole binaries.

• The analysis of IGR J170913624's variability patterns, particularly the 'heartbeat' oscillations, indicates that the most likely difference between GRS 1915+105 and IGR J170913624 is in the spins of their respective black holes. IGR J170913624 is found to have a very low spin, which could be retrograde for certain inclination angles, making it the first known astrophysical source with a retrograde spin. This finding suggests that the faintness of IGR J170913624 might be due to its low or negative spin, contrasting with GRS 1915+105, which is known for its high spin.

• The text describes a method for determining extinction curve parameters, specifically the extinction law parameter \(x\math0\), using ultraviolet color excesses. The method involves using a weighted least squares minimization technique to account for observational errors in the data, and it considers various sources of statistical and systematic errors. The results provide insights into the behavior of \(x\math0\) as a function of galactic coordinates and its variation with different calibrations of the ultraviolet color excess \(x\math46\).

• The study extends the analysis of previous works by incorporating a more rigorous treatment of errors, including mismatch errors that affect color excesses, and by using a weighted minimization procedure to determine the extinction law parameter \(x\math0\). The results are presented in tables and figures, showing the distribution of \(x\math0\) values across the sky and their comparison with different calibrations of \(x\math46\), providing a check on the universality of the extinction law across various parts of the spectrum.

* The text discusses an @xmath0-hypergeometric system @xmath1, which is a @xmath4-module determined by an integral matrix @xmath0 and a complex parameter vector @xmath5. These systems are also known as Gelfand-Kapranov-Zelevinsky (GKZ) systems.
* The solutions to these systems occur naturally in mathematics and physics, including the study of polynomial roots, Picard-Fuchs equations, and generating functions for intersection numbers on moduli spaces of curves.
* The (holonomic) rank of @xmath1 coincides with the dimension of its solution space at a nonsingular point. The text provides a combinatorial formula for the rank of @xmath1 in terms of certain lattice translates determined by @xmath0 and @xmath6.
* A subset @xmath12 of the column set of @xmath0 is called a face of @xmath0 if it is a face of the cone generated by @xmath0. The text introduces variables @xmath16 and operators @xmath17 associated with @xmath0.
* The text defines the Weyl algebra @xmath23 and the generalized @xmath0-hypergeometric system @xmath34 associated to a toric module @xmath29. It also discusses the relationship between the rank of @xmath0-hypergeometric systems and the exceptional and ranking arrangements of @xmath29.
* The text provides a description of the Euler-Koszul complex of maximal Cohen-Macaulay toric face modules and uses it to understand the images of maps between such modules. It also introduces the concept of a ranking toric module, which plays a pivotal role in calculating the rank jump @xmath62.

* The text discusses the use of a quantum computer, specifically focusing on quantum computation using qubits and quantum logical gates.
* Qubits are the basic elements in quantum computation, and they can be constructed using semiconductor quantum dots with controlled electron numbers or electron spin.
* The text highlights the use of electron spin as a promising method for encoding qubits, with longer decoherence times being an advantage.
* The manipulation of qubits can be done through electron spin resonance, and the read-out can be achieved via currents in spin-polarized leads.
* The text introduces the concept of a decoherence-free subspace (DFS) in a double quantum dot (DQD) system, which is immune to decoherence processes.
* The proposal of a three coherently coupled quantum dots (TQD) system is discussed, which can work as a qubit with improved control and operations.
* The text describes experimental efforts to achieve coherent spin manipulations in a linear TQD system, including initialization, coherent exchange, and decoherence of qubit states.
* The paper proposes a new detection method for qubit states, the doublet blockade effect, which is related to asymmetry in tunnel rates from source and drain electrodes to the TQD system.

* The symbiotic system Z Andromedae (Z And) consists of a cool giant and a hot compact component.
* Outbursts in Z And have been reported in 1915, 1939, 1960, 1984, and 2000, characterized by non-uniform eruptions of classical outbursts.
* The 1984-1986 outburst is notable for its double peak structure and low brightness.
* Outbursts are explained by the collision of the white dwarf (WD) wind with two shells ejected from the red giant (RG).
* The minimum between the two peaks is accompanied by a dip in the ionization parameter, attributed to the sudden increase in distance between the WD and the downstream nebula.
* The sharp drop in the ionization parameter is due to the collision of the WD wind with a new shell in the RG atmosphere, preventing the formation of grains.
* The outburst did not reach its maximum luminosity because the collision of the wind network was distorted by the incoming shell.
* Small peaks before and after the 1984-1986 burst are likely due to RG shell ejections.
* The periodicity of the maxima is approximately 300-400 days.
* The 2000-2002 outburst showed broad wings in line profiles and the appearance of collimated bipolar jets, not observed during the 1984-1986 outburst.

• The text discusses the investigation of frequency- and electric field-dependent conductivity in single-walled carbon nanotube (SWCNT) networks, emphasizing the importance of understanding their electrical properties for various applications. 

• The study reveals that the onset frequency extracted from frequency dependence measurements increases with film thickness, while the length scale extracted from electric field dependent measurements decreases simultaneously. An empirical relation between these two transport measurement methods is developed.

• The research also explores the nonlinear behavior of resistance in electric fields, showing that the critical field (characteristic electric field at which nonlinear conductance begins) increases with temperature and depends on the film thickness, indicating the influence of inter-bundle junctions on transport properties.

• An approximate empirical formula relating the onset frequency and nonlinear transport length scale is established, providing a connection between frequency and electric field-dependent conductivity, which aids in understanding the electrical transport properties of SWCNT films.

• The text discusses the implementation of a three-qubit Grover's algorithm using four-level superconducting quantum interference devices (SQUIDs) coupled to a superconducting resonator. The SQUIDs are designed to operate in a strong coupling limit, which facilitates the realization of quantum logic gates.

• The algorithm involves three-qubit phase gates and single-qubit gates, with a focus on reducing the number of quantum gates required for the Grover's algorithm. The text also addresses the effects of imperfections such as spontaneous decay and cavity decay on the performance of the algorithm.

• The implementation scheme does not require adjustments of level spacing during the operation, which suppresses decoherence caused by such adjustments. It also avoids the need for slowly changing Rabi frequencies and second-order detuning, leading to a faster implementation time of the order of nanoseconds.

• The text considers the influence of unwanted off-resonant interactions during gate implementation and incorporates the effects of imperfections in the system, such as decay of the cavity field and relevant levels. Despite these imperfections, the algorithm can still search for the marked state with high fidelity.

• In the 1970s, many-body theory experienced significant growth, particularly in its application to x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra.
• The focus was on the effects of many-body interactions on XPS spectra, especially from core levels in metals.
• Singularities appeared near spectral edges due to these interactions.
• Conduction band (CB) electrons can influence the XPS peak from core levels in various ways.
• If excitation is considered adiabatic, the core hole screening by CB electrons leads to a peak shift to higher kinetic energy.
• However, when excitation is swift, the CB electrons are excited, leading to a nonequilibrium state.
• This results in plasmon replicas in the spectrum, with the main peak corresponding to the system in quasi-equilibrium.
• Single-particle excitations also occur, contributing to a deformation of the main peak and plasmon replicas.
• The low-energy tailing characteristic of metallic systems can be used to determine the core hole's position in complex samples.
• Several parameters were introduced by Doniach and Sunji to characterize XPS line shapes, which are still widely used.
• The work focuses on pristine and doped graphene, showing that the chemical potential's position affects the core-hole spectra.
• In pristine graphene, the system is special due to its fermi surface, leading to a low-energy tailing.
• Doped graphene shows a tailing and contributions from 2D plasmons, which differ from those in 3D systems.
• Calculating core-hole spectra for graphene is more feasible than using Doniach and Sunji fitting methods.
• The text provides a model and derivation for calculating XPS spectra in 2D systems, including graphene.
• The model is based on Langreth's approach, modified and extended for the graphene problem.
• The core-hole spectra are derived for a 2D system, with results compared to experimental spectra.
• The text concludes with a summary and highlights the importance of considering 2D plasmons in graphene spectra.

* The text discusses the processes underlying Darwinian evolution, focusing on selection, random genetic drift, and mutations.
* Traditionally, population geneticists have analyzed these processes in the simplest setting of two genotypes.
* A genotype represents an individual's genetic makeup, and fitness is the key concept, representing selection pressure and the expected number of offspring.
* It is usually assumed that individuals have fixed fitnesses defined solely by their genotype.
* However, experimental studies have revealed that many natural systems exhibit frequency-dependent selection, where an individual's fitness depends on its interactions with other individuals and the frequency of different genotypes in the population.
* Early studies by Crow and Kimura considered frequency-dependent selection, but it has received more attention recently.
* Theoretical and computational studies represent individuals' interactions using interaction matrices from game theory, leading to a linear frequency dependence.
* Nonlinear dependencies on coevolutionary dynamics have not been extensively investigated.
* The article shows that nonlinear frequency dependence can induce new stable configurations in evolutionary dynamics and studies the impact of asymmetric mutation probabilities.
* The Moran process, a well-established model for studying evolutionary dynamics, is used in the analysis, keeping the population size constant.
* The stationary probability distribution of the system dynamics is derived using the Fokker-Planck equation, revealing metastable points and stochastic switching dynamics between multiple stable points.

• The phase-field method has become the preferred technique for simulating microstructure formation during solidification due to its algorithmic simplicity.
• It avoids the complexity of tracking moving solid-liquid interfaces or grain boundaries by describing geometry through phase fields.
• Phase fields follow simple partial differential equations that are easily coded using standard numerical methods.
• The method's foundations and application to solidification have been extensively reviewed, but this paper focuses on unresolved issues.
• Topics include the thin-interface limit, orientation-field models for polycrystalline solidification, and the inclusion of microscopic fluctuations.
• Challenges and limitations in straightforward computations are highlighted, emphasizing the need for further research.
• The method's precision and performance have been enhanced through detailed control of its properties.
• The phase-field method's equations can often be derived intuitively, but their detailed properties require mathematical analysis.
• The paper aims to point out potential pitfalls and stimulate discussions to address these issues, advancing the method's development.

• The text discusses the importance of fundamental atmospheric parameters (effective temperature, surface gravity, metallicity) and physical parameters (mass, age) of stars in chemo-dynamical studies of galaxies, particularly the Milky Way. It highlights the role of spectroscopic surveys like SEGUE, RAVE, GAIA-ESO, and HERMES in inferring the characteristics of different stellar populations.

• The text emphasizes the key importance of spectroscopic methods in determining stellar parameters, particularly metallicity, which can only be accurately measured through spectroscopy. It also discusses the use of high-resolution spectroscopy to correct low-resolution results and the common method of deriving atmospheric parameters using the information from Fe and Fe absorption lines under the assumptions of hydrostatic equilibrium and local thermodynamic equilibrium. The text also addresses the issue of non-local thermodynamic equilibrium (NLTE) effects and the development of sophisticated methods to reconcile these effects for deriving accurate spectroscopic parameters.

• The document discusses the detection of weak gravitational lensing effects on high-redshift supernovae (SNe) using their magnitudes and the distribution of foreground galaxies. It highlights the use of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) Apertif Plate (APM) galaxies as a tracer of mass density.

• It explains that brighter SNe are found behind regions of higher galaxy density, indicating that the SNe are behind more nearby mass concentrations. This is quantified by a relation between the absolute magnitude of SNe and the rank of galaxies around them, with a slope of -0.3, suggesting that brighter SNe have an excess of galaxies in their foregrounds.

• The study uses statistical tests to confirm the significance of this relation, finding it to be robust against variations in parameters such as the size of the circles around SNe and the median redshift of the foreground galaxies. It also rules out the possibility that the observed effect is due to galactic dust obscuration.

• The document presents a simple lensing model that reproduces the observed relation between SNe magnitudes and galaxy ranks, demonstrating that the slope of the relation depends on the amount and distribution of matter, but not on the specifics of the biasing scheme. This suggests that the observed effect is a signature of weak gravitational lensing.

• The implications of this finding are discussed, including its potential to provide a cleaner probe of the mass distribution at intermediate scales compared to other lensing methods. The study also addresses the impact of weak lensing on the determination of global cosmological parameters, concluding that it likely did not bias the derived values of the Hubble constant and dark energy equation of state in the current sample of 50 SNe.

• The text discusses the Lattice Dynamical Mean Field Theory (DMFT) approach to study heavy fermion (HF) metals, focusing on the Local Moment Approach (LMA) for solving the Anderson model.

• The LMA provides a two-self-energy description that captures the correlated spin-flip dynamics in HF systems, leading to a coherent fermi liquid state at low temperatures.

• The properties of HF materials are typically anomalous, with resistivity showing non-monotonic temperature dependence and rich optical structure across various frequencies.

• The absence of exact results for the Anderson model has spurred the development of approximation schemes, with the LMA being a significant framework that has gained prominence in recent years.

• The LMA is capable of handling strong interactions and provides a non-perturbative description of the system, making it suitable for studying the properties of HF materials.

• The text highlights the importance of the low-energy coherence scale (ξ) in determining the universal scaling behavior of properties in the strongly correlated regime.

• The LMA results for single-particle dynamics, scattering rates, and transport properties are presented, showing scaling behavior that depends on the coherence scale (ξ) rather than interaction strength.

• Optical conductivity results are discussed, emphasizing the role of the low-energy coherence scale in setting the intrinsic scale for the frequency dependence and thermal evolution of the optical properties.

• The text contrasts the behavior of optical conductivity in HF metals and kondo insulators, with the latter showing a gap in the optical conductivity that fills up with increasing temperature, unlike the HF metals.

• The text concludes by emphasizing the importance of considering the low-energy coherence scale in understanding the properties of HF materials, particularly in the context of transport and optical conductivity.

• The text discusses the study of polymer loop formation, focusing on the effects of static and fluctuating tensions on the process. It uses Brownian dynamics simulations and one-dimensional theory to analyze the looping time under tension.

• For static tension, the study finds that even minute tensions can significantly increase the looping time, especially for longer chains. This sensitivity is attributed to the cooperativity arising from the chain's connectivity.

• In the case of time-dependent tension, the looping time exhibits a resonant minimum at an optimal flipping time of the dichotomically fluctuating tension. This is an extension of the resonant activation phenomenon observed in single particle crossing over fluctuating barriers.

• The results are consistent with recent experiments on both static and fluctuating tensions, suggesting that biopolymers can self-organize optimally by utilizing ambient nonequilibrium fluctuations. Further experiments with dichotomically fluctuating tension are proposed to confirm the resonant activation phenomena in polymer loop formation.

* Tidal interactions are crucial in the dynamics of close binary systems, affecting phenomena like synchronization, orbital circularization, tidal capture, disruption, and orbital evolution.
* The tidal interaction between a star and a point source (star or planet) can lead to the fall of the point source onto the star, influenced by the star's evolution.
* The evolution time scales of the eccentricity or semimajor axis depend strongly on the binary system's orbital period, which can be up to 10^8 years for periods around 5 days.
* Stellar evolution should be considered on such long time scales, affecting the orbital parameters due to tidal interactions.
* The problem of determining tidal evolution is reduced to determining stellar perturbation normal modes and energy/ angular momentum exchange in the star-point source system.
* Low-frequency g-modes of stellar oscillations play a significant role in the theory of dynamical tides.
* For small periastron distances, the dimensionless excitation frequency corresponds to g-modes, indicating intense tidal interactions.
* The discovery of short-period massive planets with low eccentricities suggests the importance of tidal interactions.
* The results can be directly applied to systems like YBP1194, where a short-period planet orbits a solar twin.
* The study considers the evolution of stars with masses of one, one and a half, and two solar masses, without accounting for their rotation or magnetic field.
* The overlap integral, a measure of tidal interaction intensity, is crucial in the theory of dynamical tides and is directly related to tidal resonance coefficients.
* The change in orbital semimajor axis and eccentricity is determined by energy and angular momentum conservation laws, with specific time scales for low eccentricities.
* The stellar structure, including the presence of convective and radiative regions, affects the g-mode spectrum and overlap integrals, influencing tidal interactions.
* The study presents results on the change in orbital period for planets around stars of different masses, considering stellar evolution.
* The overlap integrals and evolution time scales of orbital parameters are calculated for stars with masses of one, one and a half, and two solar masses.
* The results show that planets with orbital periods shorter than a certain threshold will fall onto the star during the main-sequence lifetime of the star, considering its evolution.

* The text discusses pushing the resolution limits of light microscopy and understanding optical phenomena below the diffraction limit, known as nano-optics.
* Early work focused on near-field optical microscopy, but recent advancements have enabled far-field imaging with nanometer resolution through new fluorescence microscopy techniques.
* These methods rely on accurately localizing individual fluorescent markers, which are isolated based on optical characteristics or activation states.
* Determining the location of an isolated fluorescent marker is limited by photon noise, not the diffraction barrier.
* A key challenge is the optical transparency of media surrounding light emitters, particularly in biological tissues or soft matter systems that scatter photons.
* Fluorescence microscopy provides non-invasive imaging of cellular interiors and detects specific constituents through tagging, but scattering can blur images.
* Techniques like fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) exist to measure distances between emitters without imaging their positions, but they are not sensitive to scattering issues.
* The paper introduces a new approach to obtain information about the relative distance between two identical, incoherent point sources in a disordered environment by analyzing intensity fluctuations.
* This method is based on the analysis of the intensity-intensity correlation function and intensity fluctuations in the speckle pattern formed by two identical, mutually incoherent point sources.
* The approach allows monitoring the relative distance between sources in the range of 10-500 nm, with precision not limited by diffraction but by the microstructure of the scattering medium.
* The results illustrate that multiple scattering can enhance sensing, imaging, and communication techniques, as demonstrated in spatio-temporal focusing, wavefront shaping, and improving information capacity in telecommunication channels.
* The paper considers two point light sources in a disordered medium, characterized by fluctuating electric dipole moments, and derives equations for the total emitted power and intensity fluctuations.
* The method relies on averaging over the temporal fluctuations of the sources and the configurations of the disordered medium to retrieve information about the relative distance between the sources.
* The results suggest that intensity measurements at a single point in a speckle pattern can provide information about the relative distance between incoherent sources, offering an alternative to green's function retrieval techniques.
* The quantum optical equivalent of the derived equations for fluorescent emitters might involve decay rate or photocount statistics, with fluctuations associated with super-radiant and sub-radiant states, left for future work.

• The text presents a theoretical framework for understanding the inelastic nonlinear mechanical behavior of sticky biopolymer networks, represented on a mean-field level by a test polymer described by the glassy wormlike chain (GWL) model. The model allows for a dynamically evolving thermodynamic state variable characterizing the network of reversible sticky bonds, which is updated upon bond breaking according to a rate equation.

• The model predicts a pronounced fluidization response upon strong deformations, which develops on top of the intrinsic viscoelastic stiffening response provided by the individual polymers. After cessation of loading, the system slowly recovers its initial state. These observations are in qualitative agreement with recent experimental results obtained for living cells.

• The yield force for the onset of fluidization is sensitive to the deformation rate, and the fluidization response is accompanied by a cyclic softening or shake-down effect. The spatial heterogeneity of biopolymer solutions, represented by a distribution of entanglement lengths, leads to a smoothing of force-displacement curves without affecting their qualitative characteristics.

• The document discusses the stabilization of topological mott insulators (TMIs) on a honeycomb lattice, focusing on the role of Coulomb repulsions and the suppression of Fermi velocities to stabilize TMIs against competing orders like charge density waves (CDWs). It introduces the mean-field approximation and variational Monte Carlo (VMC) methods to study the phase transitions in the extended Hubbard model.

• The study reveals that the long-range CDW becomes more stable than previously estimated CDWs with smaller unit cells, especially when the electronic transfer is limited to nearest neighbor pairs. Suppressing the Fermi velocity at the Dirac point is crucial for stabilizing TMIs, which can be achieved by introducing third-neighbor hopping in the honeycomb lattice model. The document also explores the stabilization of TMIs in twisted bilayer graphene, where the Fermi velocity can be tuned by changing the rotation angle between layers.

• The research highlights the importance of controlling Coulomb repulsions and Fermi velocities to stabilize TMIs, with implications for the realization of two-dimensional TMIs in real materials like twisted bilayer graphene. It suggests that further experimental methods for controlling the stability of TMIs and ab initio quantitative estimates for bilayer graphene are needed for future studies.

* The text discusses the interest in graphene from various communities, focusing on its potential for atomic scale circuit devices and new topological phases.
* It highlights the realization of a gate-induced band gap in Bernal-stacked bi-layer graphene, which brings the graphene-based transistor closer to reality.
* The sub-gap conductance measured by researchers shows that the gapped bilayer is not as insulating as expected, introducing a new puzzle.
* The paper predicts the existence of topological gapless channels of transport along a recently imaged AB-BA tilt boundary network, solving the puzzle.
* This topological edge state holds the promise of the first realization of a topological surface state hosted by a structural topological defect.
* The lattice dislocations in three-dimensional crystals, previously discussed, are not directly accessible, but the tilt boundaries have been recently observed.
* The text proposes feasible experiments to detect topological edge states at naturally occurring tilt boundaries and makes the first concrete application of the spt approach for two-dimensional systems.

• The text discusses ionizable polymers, including polyelectrolytes and polyampholytes, which dissociate in polar solvents like water into charged macromolecules and counterions.
• Polyelectrolytes have a single sign of charged monomers, while polyampholytes have both positive and negative charged monomers.
• These polymers are often water-soluble and have applications in industry and medicine.
• Biological macromolecules such as DNA, RNA, and proteins are examples of charged polymers.
• Charged polymers have been a subject of interest in polymer science for several decades.
• In a polyelectrolyte chain, intra-chain electrostatic interactions are repulsive, causing swelling, whereas in a polyampholyte, attractive interactions between oppositely charged monomers decrease chain size.
• The sequence of charged monomers on polyampholyte chains affects behaviors like aggregation and self-assembly.
• Charged monomer sequences in charge-symmetric polyampholytes impact their adsorption properties to charged surfaces.
• Polyelectrolyte brushes, formed by anchored charged polymers, exhibit electrostatic interactions that introduce additional length scales.
• In polyelectrolyte brushes, repulsive electrostatic forces between chains can lead to a brush regime at low grafting densities.
• At high grafting densities and charge fractions, counterions are trapped inside the polyelectrolyte brush, affecting its thickness.
• The thickness of a polyelectrolyte brush depends linearly on the grafting density, with theoretical and simulation methods predicting this behavior.
• The strength of this linear dependence varies with the chains' flexibility, with brushes of flexible chains showing weaker dependence compared to semiflexible and rodlike chains.
• The equilibrium conformations of brushes of different polyampholytes are influenced by the chains' properties, such as fraction and sequence of charged monomers and bending energy.
• Brushes of flexible, semiflexible, and rodlike diblock polyampholytes were studied using molecular dynamics simulations, revealing linear dependence of average thickness on grafting density.
• The linear dependence of average thickness on grafting density is described using a simple scaling method applicable to brushes of flexible chains.
• Finite-size effects were considered in simulations, showing that the chains do not overlap with their own images, justifying the focus on smaller brushes for computational efficiency.

• The text discusses the use of scalar diquark fields to construct tetraquark currents for studying nonet scalar mesons below the Λc threshold. It introduces new quantum fields and sum rules to analyze the mesons' structures, focusing on overcoming the embarrassment of using colored diquarks as basic constituents in meson and baryon spectroscopy. The article also presents numerical results and discussions on the masses and pole residues of the nonet tetraquark states, comparing them with experimental data and theoretical estimations.

• The text highlights the importance of considering the scalar diquarks as basic constituents in the construction of tetraquark currents for studying nonet scalar mesons. It emphasizes the advantage of using diquark currents in satisfying the two criteria of the QCD sum rules more easily compared to conventional quark currents. The new sum rules can be extended to study other multiquark states, offering a new spectroscopy for mesons and baryons. The work is supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China and the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities.

• The paper discusses the application of pseudo-transient continuation (PTC) in power system long-term stability analysis, aiming to accelerate simulation speed and overcome numerical difficulties in quasi-steady-state (QSS) models. PTC is a theoretically-based numerical method that follows the solution of dynamical systems accurately until the steady state is approached, then increases the time step to gain rapid convergence. This method is particularly useful in power systems with complex features such as discontinuities, where it can help reach the steady state quickly while maintaining good accuracy for intermittent trajectories.

• The paper presents a modified implementation of PTC for both the long-term stability model and the QSS model in power systems. For the long-term stability model, PTC is applied directly to accelerate simulation speed compared to conventional implicit integration methods. In the QSS model, PTC is used to overcome possible numerical difficulties due to its good stability property. The paper includes three numerical examples demonstrating the feasibility and effectiveness of the modified PTC method in providing correct stability assessment and overcoming numerical difficulties in the QSS model, while also offering good accuracy for intermediate trajectories.

• The text discusses the increasing interest in anisotropic quantum scattering in two spatial dimensions (2D), stimulated by the potential creation of exotic quantum systems with dipolar gases.

• It covers various phenomena such as anisotropic superfluidity, 2D dipolar fermions, and few-body dipolar complexes, highlighting the recent experimental production of ultracold polar molecules in optical traps.

• The text notes the long history of research on 2D quantum effects in condensed matter physics, including superfluid films, high-temperature superconductivity, 2D materials like graphene, and topological quantum computation.

• The development of experimental techniques for creating quasi-2D Bose and fermi ultracold gases has provided unique opportunities for modeling these 2D effects in a highly controlled environment.

• The text focuses on the analysis of 2D dipolar scattering, particularly the inefficiency of usual partial-wave analysis due to the strong anisotropic coupling of different partial waves in the asymptotic region.

• It describes a method for quantitative analysis of 2D quantum scattering on a long-range, strongly anisotropic scatterer, applicable to collisions of unpolarized dipoles, and its successful application to problems like scattering on a cylindrical potential and dipole-dipole scattering.

• G65.2@Xmath05.7, initially ignored after its radio and optical images and spectra were recorded, has recently become interesting due to its potential role in explaining thermal composite supernova remnants (SNRs).
• These SNRs exhibit a combination of a shell-like radio continuum morphology and a centrally bright X-ray morphology, with X-ray emission attributed to thermal rather than synchrotron processes.
• The origins of thermal composite SNRs are mysterious, with various hypotheses suggesting they may have evolved into the radiative phase, experienced enhanced central densities through processes like cloudlet evaporation or metallicities increase, or resulted from collisions with molecular clouds.
• G65.2@Xmath05.7 is now considered a thermal composite SNR, demonstrating it is in the radiative phase, which is not typically observed as a "smoking gun" for this phase.
• The remnant's classification as a thermal composite SNR is supported by its shell-like radio continuum morphology, thermal X-ray emission, and centrally filled X-ray morphology, confirmed through archival ROSAT observations.

* The text discusses the encoding of permutations, which are fundamental in representing integer functions, strings, and binary relations.
* Permutations can be trivially represented in a number of bits close to the information theory lower bound, making them efficient for storage.
* Efficient computation of both a permutation and its inverse is often required in various applications.
* The lower bound of bits for sorting a permutation in the comparison model yields a comparison lower bound, but many algorithms can perform better by exploiting specific permutation structures.
* Examples of easy permutations include those sorted in identity, containing sorted blocks, or having sorted subsequences, which can be sorted with fewer comparisons.
* There are classes of permutations with interesting structures that are useful for applications, and their study can lead to more efficient encoding schemes.
* The entropy of a sequence of positive integers, which adds up to a given number, is defined and used in the context of succinctly encoding sequences.
* Succinct encodings of sequences, including bitmaps, are discussed, focusing on operations like counting occurrences and positions of symbols.
* The text introduces encoding schemes for permutations that use a number of bits close to the entropy of the permutation's run lengths, supporting operations like applying the permutation and its inverse in time proportional to the number of bits used.

* The paper discusses the discovery of chimera states in populations of identical phase oscillators under nonlocal symmetric coupling, which was given the name chimera state due to its highly counterintuitive nature. These states have been studied extensively in various models, including Kuramoto phase oscillators, periodic and chaotic maps, and Stuart-Landau oscillators.
* The first experimental evidence of chimera states was found in populations of coupled chemical oscillators and optical coupled-map lattices. The paper also mentions the emergence of chimeras in a mechanical experiment involving two subpopulations of identical metronomes coupled in a hierarchical network.
* In the context of neuroscience, the paper explores the possibility that chimera states might explain the phenomenon of unihemispheric sleep observed in many birds and dolphins. The study focuses on identifying various single and multi-chimera states in networks of non-locally coupled neurons represented by Hindmarsh-Rose oscillators.
* The paper contributes to the field by identifying a variety of single and multi-chimera states in networks of non-locally coupled neurons using Hindmarsh-Rose oscillators. It also discusses the dynamics of these states in both 2D and 3D models, highlighting the importance of nonlocal coupling in the emergence of chimera states.

• Kauffman networks are disordered dynamical systems proposed by Kauffman in 1969 as a model for genetic regulatory systems, attracting interest from physicists in the 80s due to their analogy with disordered systems in statistical mechanics.
