* DOD, in response to congressional pressure, established a task force to identify personnel exposed to chemical substances, resulting in the identification of approximately 6,400 servicemembers and civilians.
* DOD has continued efforts to identify individuals exposed to chemical or biological substances outside of Project 112, a specific DOD program, but has faced challenges in defining objectives, scope, and information needs, as well as in oversight and coordination with other entities.

* The government of Mexico has sought to combat the growing power of criminal groups, including DTOs, for almost a decade.
* In 2006, President Felipe Calderón mobilized military and law enforcement agencies to disrupt DTO operations and target leadership structures.
* Under President Enrique Peña Nieto, there has been a shift in emphasis toward reducing criminal violence that threatens civilians and the business sector.
* DTOs require a constant supply of firearms and ammunition to assert control, eliminate rivals, enforce illicit business dealings, and resist government operations.
* The majority of firearms seized in Mexico and traced back to the United States originate from Texas, California, and Arizona.
* ATF and ICE have taken steps to improve coordination on efforts to combat firearms trafficking, including signing a 2009 interagency collaboration memorandum of understanding (MOU).
* The MOU sets forth roles and requirements for each agency with respect to intelligence and information sharing, general and specific investigative guidelines, sources of information, and conflict resolution.
* ATF and ICE disagree on the extent to which trace data on firearms seized in Mexico collected through eTrace should be shared to support ICE firearms trafficking investigations.
* The National Southwest Border Counternarcotics Strategy (Strategy) includes strategic objectives and indicators for each of its nine issue chapters, but the indicator for the Weapons Chapter does not adequately measure progress in stemming the flow of illegal weapons across the border.

• NCHIP, managed by the Bureau of Justice Statistics (BJS), provides federal grants to states to build a national infrastructure for exchanging criminal history and relevant records, focusing on improving accuracy, completeness, and accessibility.

• States have used NCHIP funds primarily for National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS) purposes, such as criminal records improvements and disposition reporting, with some funds allocated for automated fingerprint identification, sex offender registry enhancements, and protection order activities.

• States have made progress in automating criminal history records and making them accessible nationally, with the percentage of automated records increasing from 79% in 1993 to 89% in 2001. However, challenges remain in automating disposition information and providing information on specific disqualifying factors.

• NCHIP's goal is to enhance public safety by improving criminal history records systems, and BJS is developing a criminal history records quality index (RQI) to assess and monitor performance across jurisdictions.

• Factors for policymakers to consider in debating NCHIP's future include the need for ongoing improvements, growing demand for background checks, technological advancements, and the importance of a national infrastructure for public safety.

* The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) established the Superfund program in 1980 to address the nation's most severely contaminated hazardous waste sites.
* EPA investigates contaminated areas and places the most highly contaminated sites on the National Priorities List (NPL) for study and cleanup.
* As of December 1996, there were 1,210 sites on the NPL.
* After a site is placed on the NPL, EPA studies and evaluates the site to determine the appropriate cleanup remedy.
* Incineration is one of the cleanup remedies used by EPA, accounting for about 6% of the decisions on remedies through fiscal year 1995.
* Three incinerators were operating at Superfund sites at the time of the review: Bayou Bonfouca in Louisiana, Times Beach in Missouri, and Baird and McGuire in Massachusetts.
* Incineration involves four basic steps: waste preparation, burning, ash collection, and gas treatment.
* EPA requires incinerators at Superfund sites to meet Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) standards, including emissions standards.
* EPA establishes site-specific standards for emissions and operations, incorporates safety features into emergency systems, monitors emissions, and provides 24-hour on-site oversight.
* EPA planned to use incineration at four additional sites as of October 1996.
* EPA did not fully implement two methods to promote safe operation of Superfund incinerators: regular inspections by RCRA hazardous waste incinerator inspectors and systematic sharing of lessons learned from site to site.

• The SEC's financial statements for fiscal years 2007 and 2006 were found to be fairly stated in all material respects, despite identified weaknesses in internal control that may affect financial reporting and other decisions based on the information.

• The SEC had one material weakness and three significant control deficiencies in internal control, primarily related to the period-end financial reporting process, disgorgements and penalties accounts receivable, accounting for transaction fee revenue, and preparing financial statement disclosures. These weaknesses collectively constituted a material weakness in the SEC's financial reporting process.

• The U.S. Postal Service (Service) had about 765,000 career employees at the end of fiscal year 1997, with the Executive and Administrative Schedule (EAS) workforce consisting primarily of employees in EAS 11 through 26 positions. At the end of fiscal year 1997, EAS positions totaled 80,238, or about 10 percent of total Service career-level employees.

• The Service's Diversity Development Department was established in 1992 to foster an inclusive business environment and actively support the recruitment, retention, and upward mobility of women and minorities. The Service's 1999 Annual Performance Plan includes achieving a diverse workforce as one of its goals.

• A 6-month study by Aguirre International in 1997 found that the Service was a leader in meeting affirmative action goals and striving for parity between its workforce and the civilian labor force. However, the study also noted that women and minorities appeared to be experiencing problems advancing to management jobs at EAS 17 and above positions.

• The Service developed an action plan in response to the Aguirre report, which included 23 initiatives aimed at strengthening its diversity program. As of December 1998, the Service reported that nine initiatives had been completed, and seven were 90 to 99 percent complete.

• The Service collects a variety of diversity-related data and has initiatives under way to improve data collection methods and use. However, the Service does not have reliable data on the flow of applicants through its promotion processes, which would help identify and remove barriers to the promotion of women and minorities.

• DOD defines Military Working Dogs (MWDs) as canines bred, procured, or acquired to support military operations, including explosive and illegal narcotic detection, patrol, tracking, and other requirements. 

• MWDs are removed from service due to medical or behavioral issues, when no longer needed, or in other circumstances. Robby's Law, enacted in 2000, promotes adoption of MWDs after their service ends.

• Disposition of MWDs involves a review board that includes the Commander of the Air Force's 341st Training Squadron, a representative of the 341st Training Squadron, a Veterinary Corps Officer, and a Veterinary Corps Officer behavioral representative. 

• Handlers interested in adopting an MWD communicate their interest to the Kennel Master, who annotates the WDMS to show the handler's interest, including adding the handler's name and contact information. 

• The Army Veterinary Service is responsible for the medical care of MWDs, including providing a recommendation letter and a consultation/referral form for adoption. The Army also maintains a veterinary care system for privately owned animals, including adopted MWDs.

• DOD uses three systems to track information about MWDs, including WDMS, the Central Repository, and ROVR. The number of MWDs adopted or transferred has varied over the past 5 years, with the highest numbers in 2012 and 2013 due to decreased deployment needs.

• Available data for 55% of MWDs adopted in 2014 and 2015 indicate prevalent medical conditions include skin, dental, and musculoskeletal issues. The potential costs for treating these conditions vary based on factors such as the course of treatment and underlying cause.

• Adopted MWDs need preventative care regardless of their medical conditions. Assistance with privately provided veterinary care is available through nonprofit organizations, such as the U.S. War Dogs Association, which offers prescription drugs, free specialty care, and financial assistance.

* The Comanche program was established in 1983 to replace the Army's light helicopter fleet, aiming for a low-cost, lightweight, advanced technology helicopter capable of armed reconnaissance and attack.
* The program faced significant challenges, including increased costs, delays, and technical issues with software development and aircraft maintainability.
* The Secretary of Defense directed restructuring in 1994 due to budgetary constraints, reducing funding and extending the development phase by 3 years.
* The Army proposed acquiring six additional aircraft beyond the two prototypes, deferring developmental efforts to fiscal year 2002, to meet the Secretary's funding constraint.
* The restructured program continues risks associated with concurrent production decisions and higher program costs, as per DOD guidelines.
* The Army plans to acquire six "early operational capability" aircraft, costing over $300 million, to better evaluate the Comanche's mission capability before committing to production.
* The program has experienced significant increases in program acquisition unit cost since 1985, with a 185% increase from the original estimate.
* Software development issues, including problems with the Ada compilation system, delays in development and testing, and configuration management, pose risks to the aircraft's performance and first flight.
* Maintainability requirements, such as direct maintenance man-hours per flight hour, mean time to repair, and fault isolation, are at risk of not being met, affecting the program's cost and availability goals.

* The Food Stamp Program provides eligible low-income households with paper coupons or electronic benefits for food purchases. FNS funds food stamp benefits and about half of the states’ administrative costs, with regulations requiring annual household eligibility certification and reporting of changes.
* To increase program access and reduce reporting burden, FNS introduced options and waivers related to eligibility, reporting, and benefits for TANF recipients. These include vehicle asset rules, categorical eligibility for food stamps based on TANF services, and reporting alternatives.
* States use various options and waivers to change food stamp eligibility and reporting processes, aiming to increase access, support working families, and simplify administration. Key options involve categorical eligibility, vehicle asset rules, and reporting alternatives like semiannual reporting.

* The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) is responsible for programs in four areas: housing assistance, community development, housing finance, and regulatory issues.
* HUD's fiscal year 2000 budget request includes 19 new initiatives and programs, totaling $210 million, with seven set-asides within existing programs.
* The largest program increase is in the Section 8 housing assistance program, with a proposed budget of $2.5 billion, raising questions about HUD's capacity to manage the increase.
* HUD's budget justification for the Section 8 program raises issues regarding the basis for contract renewal costs and the lack of estimates for costs beyond 2000, necessitating further review.

* The Military Health System, operated by DOD, has a dual mission of readiness and benefits, providing medical services to military personnel and their families.
* DOD's health care mission is carried out through military medical centers, hospitals, and clinics, both directly and through civilian providers via TRICARE.
* The TRICARE Management Activity, under Health Affairs, oversees the renovation and construction of medical facilities, including the replacement of Landstuhl Regional Medical Center (LRMC) and the 86th Medical Group clinic.
* In 2008, plans were approved to renovate LRMC and the 86th MDG clinic, with the initial LRMC plans including a new inpatient tower, emergency medicine facilities, and other clinical and support activities.
* In 2009, a cost-benefit analysis recommended consolidating LRMC and the 86th MDG into a single facility, leading to the current plan for a new medical center adjacent to Ramstein Air Base.
* The new medical center will be operated by the Army and provide tertiary care for beneficiaries in the European, Central Command, and Africa Command theaters.
* DOD officials considered beneficiary population data, contingency operations, and troop strength when developing facility requirements, but recent posture changes are currently being assessed for their impact.
* The beneficiary population expected to receive care from the new medical center is primarily located within a 55-mile radius of its site.
* The new medical center is designed for peacetime operations but has the capacity to expand during surges to handle casualties from contingency operations.
* DOD has been reducing its military posture in Europe, and the new medical center is being sized for peacetime operations, with the flexibility to expand during surges.
* DOD has been conducting sensitivity analyses to assess the impact of potential changes in beneficiary population on facility requirements and sizing.

• The report examines how Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) ensures fair, reasoned, and efficient use of discretion in alien apprehension and removal decisions.

• ICE officers exercise discretion during the initial phases of the process, particularly in initiating removals, apprehending aliens, issuing removal documents, and detaining aliens.

• Discretion is limited for aliens who are investigation targets, such as criminals, but more latitude exists for aliens not targeted in investigations, especially those with humanitarian issues.

• The alien apprehension and removal process includes six phases, with the initial phases involving the most discretion.

• ICE officers consider factors like humanitarian concerns and ICE priorities when deciding to grant voluntary departure or issue a Notice to Appear (NTA).

• ICE attorneys and Detention and Removal Operations (DRO) officers have less discretion in later phases of the process, with decisions largely guided by policy and guidelines.

• ICE has updated some training for officers responsible for making alien apprehension and removal decisions, but guidance on exercising discretion in cases involving humanitarian issues and non-targeted aliens is not comprehensive.

• ICE lacks a mechanism to ensure consistent dissemination of legal developments necessary for making alien apprehension and removal decisions.

• ICE does not have a mechanism to collect and analyze data on officers' exercise of discretion, which could provide additional assurance that decisions comply with established policies and procedures.

• Medicare payments for ambulance services consist of a service-level payment for the type of transport and a mileage payment.

• Ambulance services can be affiliated with institutions, be independent, or be for-profit, nonprofit, or government-based.

• Revenue sources for ambulance providers include community tax support, charitable donations, in-kind contributions, state and federal grants, subscription programs, and payments from Medicare, Medicaid, and private health insurance companies.

• The Medicare ambulance payment formula includes a service-level payment for the type of transport and a mileage payment based on miles traveled.

• Providers with lower transport volumes tend to have higher costs per transport due to fixed costs for maintaining readiness.

• The median cost per ground ambulance transport in 2010 was $429, with a range from $224 to $2,204.

• Super-rural providers had higher estimated median costs per transport compared to urban providers.

• Ambulance transports for Medicare beneficiaries increased by 33% from 2004 to 2010, with the largest growth in super-rural areas.

• The increase in ambulance transports was not attributed to changes in beneficiary demographics, but possibly to increased billing practices and the national fee schedule.

• The Department of Defense's (DOD) Supply Chain Integration office is responsible for leading the development of DOD supply chain policies and improving accountability, visibility, and control of critical assets, including SRC I ammunition.

• The Army procures a majority of DOD's ammunition and provides wholesale storage for other military services at Army depots. Army depots ship SRC I ammunition owned by other services to their respective locations upon request.

• SRC I ammunition may also be located at retail locations such as military service installations, bases, and ammunition supply points. Each military service has entities responsible for the accountability, physical inventory, and transportation of SRC I ammunition.

• DOD's Military Surface Deployment and Distribution Command tracks the movement of SRC I ammunition and coordinates responses to transportation issues while in transit.

• DOD policy requires continuous program and policy oversight to ensure protection of sensitive conventional arms, ammunition, and explosives, and DOD components are required to track and conduct physical inventories of SRC I ammunition by serial number.

• The Air Force has plans to revise its guidance to track SRC I ammunition by serial number, as current systems do not have the capability to do so. Air Force policy does not require accountability in its system of record for items owned by other services and stored at Air Force locations.

• The military services generally recorded shipment and receipt of SRC I ammunition in their accountability systems, but the Army and Marine Corps do not have guidance that required receipting of SRC I ammunition in a timely manner.

• The Air Force, Navy, and Marine Corps have policies or plans regarding maintaining in-transit accountability for shipped SRC I ammunition to generally adhere to DOD requirements, but the Army's policy and processes do not fully adhere.

• The military services have not consistently ensured timely, complete, and accurate information to maintain full visibility of SRC I ammunition in the continental United States.

• The Social Security Administration (SSA) is the largest single producer, collector, and user of information in the US, responsible for issuing Social Security numbers (SSNs) and maintaining records for various federal programs.

• SSA's disclosure policy for law enforcement is more restrictive than the Privacy Act and most federal agencies, aiming to protect individuals' privacy while cooperating with law enforcement.

• SSA's policy requires officials to consider factors like the nature of the alleged criminal activity, the information requested, and the agency making the request before sharing personal information.

• SSA can disclose information under certain conditions, such as fraud in Social Security programs, nonviolent crimes in similar government programs, violent crimes, and provisions of other federal statutes.

• SSA's disclosure policy is contained in regulations and guidance documents, including the Program Operations Manual System (POMS) and Emergency Messages.

• SSA's Office of Inspector General (OIG) is authorized to disclose individuals' personal information to law enforcement agencies under a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with SSA.

• SSA field offices handle most requests for disclosing information, with the Privacy Officer overseeing implementation and ensuring compliance with the policy.

• SSA's disclosure policy is compared to those of other federal agencies, showing SSA's policy is more restrictive than most, aligning with IRS and Census Bureau policies.

• SSA's policy is complex and can lead to inconsistent application, with some field office staff and local law enforcement officers finding it confusing.

• GAO recommends SSA take steps to clarify its policy, provide information to law enforcement, and consider delegating decision-making authority for law enforcement requests to specified units.

* The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) was passed in 1976 and amended in 1984 to manage hazardous waste to prevent threats to human health and the environment.
* RCRA governs hazardous waste from generation to final disposal, aiming to minimize contamination risks.
* It includes provisions for identifying and listing hazardous waste based on specific criteria, such as industrial processes or characteristics like flammability.
* RCRA applies to all hazardous waste, regardless of origin, and regulates waste from both current and past industrial operations.
* It covers waste that has been mixed with hazardous substances, requiring management under RCRA until the medium no longer contains the hazardous waste.
* RCRA's requirements can increase cleanup costs and time, leading parties to choose less aggressive remedies.
* Key barriers include land disposal restrictions, minimum technological requirements, and permit requirements.
* EPA has developed policy statements and regulatory alternatives to mitigate these barriers, but they have faced challenges and inconsistencies.
* EPA proposed comprehensive reform in 1996 but plans to focus on four narrow regulatory changes due to unresolved legal and technical issues.
* Stakeholders disagree on the extent of reform needed and the role of states in managing remediation waste.
* GAO recommends steps to ensure consistent application of EPA's existing policies and alternatives to manage remediation waste under current requirements.

• CMS has allocated MIP funds primarily to support its contractors' program integrity efforts for the traditional Medicare program, known as fee-for-service Medicare. This includes activities such as audits, medical reviews, secondary payer operations, benefit integrity, and provider education.

• CMS increased its allocation for provider education by about 590% from fiscal year 1997 through fiscal year 2005, due in part to the agency's decision to use MIP funds for outreach activities to groups of like providers. Spending for medical review increased 45% during the same period.

• CMS generally spent the largest share of MIP funds on audit, averaging about 31% of total expenditures, and on medical review, averaging about 27%. CMS spent less on secondary payer, averaging 21%, and benefit integrity, averaging 15%. Provider education received the smallest percentage, averaging about 6%.

• CMS plans to use some of the $112 million in additional MIP funds provided by DRA for fiscal year 2006 to support Part D program integrity efforts, including funding efforts by Medicare prescription drug integrity contractors (MEDIC) to protect the prescription drug benefit by performing selected tasks.

* The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) has taken several actions to enhance training for screeners and supervisors, including updating training curricula, providing online learning resources, and requiring recurrent training.
* TSA monitors compliance with screener training requirements through directives and policies, but lacks clear definitions of responsibility for tracking and ensuring training completion.
* Efforts to assess and enhance screener performance in detecting threat objects include covert testing, the Threat Image Projection (TIP) system, and the annual recertification program. However, performance targets for these measures have not been established.
* TSA has developed performance indexes for the passenger and checked baggage screening systems, but has not established targets for the components of these indexes. Establishing such targets would enable more meaningful analysis of performance and improvement efforts.

* The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) faces challenges in managing its human capital to provide telephone customer service to taxpayers. These challenges include difficulties in setting long-term, desired service-level goals, recruiting and retaining customer service representatives, training representatives effectively, and scheduling staff efficiently.
* IRS has not established a long-term, desired level-of-service goal based on taxpayers' needs and the costs and benefits of meeting them. Instead, it annually determines staffing levels based on its judgment of balancing efforts to assist taxpayers and ensure compliance with tax laws. This approach is inconsistent with federal guidance on strategic planning and industry practices.
* IRS has faced challenges in successfully recruiting, training, retaining, and scheduling customer service representatives. These challenges include difficulties recruiting due to job characteristics, inadequate resources for training, and the cyclical nature of taxpayer demand. IRS is developing a national recruiting strategy and plans to provide targeted, just-in-time training. However, it lacks a system for assessing the refresher training needs of individual representatives and monitoring attrition to optimize training resources and reduce turnover.

* Ginnie Mae, a unit of HUD, operates as the dominant secondary market vehicle for government-backed loan programs, expanding affordable housing opportunities in America.
* Ginnie Mae's market share has declined over the last 20 years, both in terms of new issuances and volume outstanding, due to growth in the conventional MBS market and securitization of conventional mortgages.
* Ginnie Mae faces challenges in adjusting its product mix and policies to address changes in the marketplace while meeting the needs of borrowers and industry stakeholders.
* Ginnie Mae has taken steps to improve its product offerings, disclosures, and internal controls, but faces ongoing challenges in managing its operations and ensuring effective contract management.

* The General Accounting Office (GAO) reviewed the Department of Defense's (DOD) efforts to correct illegal and improper closed account adjustments identified in a prior audit.
* DOD agreed that $592 million of the $615 million in adjustments should not have been made and reversed these adjustments. However, reversing the transactions revealed additional accounting issues requiring detailed reviews.
* DOD plans to complete all 30 reaudits to correct fiscal year 2000 adjustments by September 2002, and an investigation into potential Antideficiency Act violations is ongoing.
* DOD's contract reconciliation system (CRS) and other controls were not in place, leading to $1.9 billion in fiscal year 2001 adjustments, of which $172 million were illegal or improper.
* DOD officials plan to review an additional $1.1 billion of fiscal year 2001 adjustments, expecting to complete reviews and reversals by December 2002, but reaudits and corrections will not be finished until September 2004.
* DOD's reported closed account adjustments dropped by about 80% in the first 6 months of fiscal year 2002 compared to the same period in fiscal year 2001, indicating improved controls.

• The Internet's domain name system relies on a set of functions called the domain name system to ensure the uniqueness of each email and website address. The U.S. government supported the implementation of this system for nearly a decade, largely through a Department of Defense contract. In 1997, the Department of Commerce began a process for transitioning the technical responsibility for the domain name system to the private sector.

• The transition effort has faced significant challenges, including slow progress on key tasks such as formal agreements with root server and country-code domain operators, and issues with ICANN's governance structure. In February 2002, ICANN's president concluded that the corporation could not succeed without fundamental reform. In response, ICANN's Board established an internal committee to recommend options for reform.

• The Department of Commerce, responsible for general oversight of the transition, has provided limited public assessment of the progress. The only report specifically called for under the MOU is a final joint project report to document the outcome of ICANN's test of the policies and procedures designed and developed under the MOU. The Department has not issued status reports or publicly commented on specific reform proposals being considered by ICANN.

* The Department of the Interior (Interior) has held funds in trust for Indian tribes since 1820, with reforms initiated in 1994.
* The Office of the Special Trustee for American Indians (OST) was established to oversee these reforms, which include developing an integrated trust management system.
* OST has made progress in implementing reforms, such as trust funds accounting system (TFAS), trust funds receivable, trust beneficiary call center, and trust portal.
* However, OST has not provided a timetable for completing remaining reforms or a date for its termination under the 1994 Act.
* OST's budget and staff have grown significantly to support trust reform activities, with a focus on trust fund management and accounting operations.
* OST has relied heavily on contractors for trust reform activities, with nearly 21% of its funds obligated to contracts in fiscal years 2004 and 2005.
* The use of contractors has raised concerns about preferential treatment, leading to ethics training for OST employees and a review of the performance of one contractor.
* The Special Trustee plans to reduce funding for contracts as reforms are completed, but has not developed a workforce plan to reassess future staffing needs.
* GAO recommends that Interior provide a timetable for completing reforms, a plan for future trust fund operations, and develop a workforce plan to reassess staffing levels.

* In 1998, VA and DOD initiated a joint effort to develop a comprehensive, lifelong medical record for service members.
* The first project, GCPR, aimed to create an electronic interface for accessing health information from both agencies' systems.
* GAO recommended improvements in management, oversight, and strategic planning for the GCPR project.
* In 2002, the project was renamed FHIE, with VA designated as the lead entity, and a memorandum of agreement was established.
* By July 2002, the first phase enabled one-way data transfer from DOD's system to a VA-accessible database.
* The second phase, completed in March 2004, added patient health information to the VA database.
* FHIE was operational by December 2004, providing data on 2.3 million unique patients.
* Total costs for GCPR/FHIE through fiscal year 2003 were approximately $85 million.
* The departments began using FHIE to transfer pre- and post-deployment health assessment data from DOD to VA.
* The long-term goal is a two-way exchange of health information between DOD and VA through the HealthePeople (Federal) initiative.
* This initiative involves developing a common health information architecture and exchanging data between future health systems.
* The departments are also working on demonstration projects to exchange information between existing systems.
* The Bidirectional Health Information Exchange (BHIE) project provides near-real-time access to patient medical information for both VA and DOD.
* The Laboratory Data Sharing Interface (LDSI) enables sharing of laboratory resources between the departments.
* The cornerstone for the two-way exchange is the CHDR initiative, which has successfully completed Phase I.
* The departments have taken steps to improve management of the CHDR project, including establishing a project management plan and structure.
* However, challenges remain, including the need for a detailed project management plan, data completeness, and security policy development.

* The Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) outlines the goal of income tax audits to determine correct taxable income and tax liability.
* IRS uses nine audit standards to ensure quality audits, covering areas like scope, techniques, technical conclusions, and time management.
* Audit workpapers are crucial for documenting the audit process, supporting conclusions, and providing basis for management review.
* IRS historically found issues with workpaper quality, with evaluations indicating compliance with standards in no more than 72% of audits.
* Inadequate workpapers can lead to additional work or overturned recommendations.
* Supervisory review is a key quality control mechanism, but documentation of these reviews in workpapers was limited in sampled audits.
* IRS is revising the IRM to require documentation of managerial involvement in the audit process.
* The lack of documentation on supervisory review raises questions about the extent of involvement and control over audit quality.

* The U.S. Department of State's Antiterrorism Assistance (ATA) program, authorized in 1983, aims to enhance partner countries' antiterrorism skills, strengthen bilateral ties, and promote human rights. It offers training and equipment to combat terrorism.
* The program's effectiveness is limited by a lack of clear guidance from the State Department's Bureau of Counterterrorism (S/CT) on which countries should receive assistance and what type. This makes it difficult to align assistance with broader U.S. counterterrorism policy goals.
* The Antiterrorism Technical Assistance (ATA) program's needs assessments and program reviews, intended to guide resource allocation and planning, have weaknesses. They do not consistently prioritize assistance or link recommendations to specific timeframes, limiting their utility in improving partner nations' counterterrorism capabilities.

• The U.S. Bankruptcy Code (Code) has not undergone significant changes specifically related to large financial company bankruptcies since GAO's last report in 2013. 
• Two bills were introduced in the 113th Congress (Taxpayer Protection and Responsible Resolution Act and Financial Institution Bankruptcy Act) that would have made changes to the Code for financial company bankruptcies, but neither was signed into law.
• The Taxpayer Protection and Responsible Resolution Act would have repealed the regulatory resolution regime in Title II of the Dodd-Frank Act, allowed the Federal Reserve to commence an involuntary bankruptcy, and granted the Federal Reserve the right to be heard before the court.
• The Financial Institution Bankruptcy Act would have allowed an involuntary bankruptcy to be commenced by the Federal Reserve and created a new subchapter under Chapter 11 for large financial companies.
• The bills would have also changed the treatment of qualified financial contracts (QFCs) in bankruptcy, including a temporary stay for QFCs and restrictions on counterparty rights.
• The 21st Century Glass-Steagall Act of 2013 would have repealed all safe harbor provisions for QFCs, but it was not signed into law.
• The safe harbor treatment of QFCs under the Code has been identified as a challenge to an orderly resolution in bankruptcy, but experts also argue that repeal could have adverse effects.
• The U.S. judicial process under bankruptcy remains the presumptive method for resolving financial institutions, even those designated as systemically important.
• The Federal Reserve and FDIC have taken certain regulatory actions mandated by the Dodd-Frank Act toward facilitating orderly resolution, including efforts that could contribute to cross-border coordination.
• International bodies, such as the Financial Stability Board, have focused on strengthening their regulatory structures to enable the orderly resolution of a failing large financial firm and have taken additional actions to facilitate cross-border resolutions.
• Comprehensive data on the number of financial companies in bankruptcies are not readily available.

* The electricity industry is composed of four functions: generation, transmission, distribution, and system operations.
* Electricity is sent through high-voltage transmission lines to local distributors, then transformed for distribution to consumers.
* System operators constantly balance power generation and consumption to maintain grid stability.
* Utilities own and operate electricity assets, including generation plants, transmission and distribution lines, and substations.
* Smart grid systems integrate new technologies and IT networks to automate management and recovery processes.
* The federal and state governments oversee the electricity industry, with FERC regulating wholesale sales and transmission.
* State regulators oversee local distribution systems, and NERC ensures grid reliability through standards and assessments.
* Cybersecurity threats to the electricity grid are evolving and can originate from unintentional or intentional sources.
* Smart grid systems have known vulnerabilities, including entry points, new technologies, and customer information exposure.
* NIST, FERC, and other entities have taken steps to secure the grid, including developing standards and guidelines.
* Challenges include monitoring implementation, clarifying regulatory responsibilities, adopting a comprehensive approach, and ensuring built-in security features.
* Effective information sharing and metrics development are crucial for enhancing cybersecurity in the industry.

• The federal workforce faces significant mission-critical skills gaps, impacting the government's ability to serve the public cost-effectively and achieve results.

• Over 34% of federal employees eligible to retire by 2020, with some agencies experiencing particularly high retirement eligibility levels.

• Turnover can be beneficial for introducing fresh skills and restructuring, but strategic monitoring and management are crucial to avoid gaps in institutional knowledge and leadership.

• Numerous tools are available for agencies to address talent needs, but issues persist in classification, recruiting, hiring, pay systems, performance management, and employee engagement.

• The General Schedule (GS) system has not kept pace with evolving government requirements, affecting its effectiveness in aligning with modern compensation principles.

• The federal pay system, based on length of service rather than individual performance, lacks alignment with market-based and performance-oriented principles.

• The composition of the federal workforce has shifted, requiring more advanced skills and education compared to the private sector.

• Balancing the size and composition of the federal workforce is a key challenge to delivering high-quality services within budget constraints.

• Agencies have been provided with exemptions from the current pay system to gain more flexibility in setting pay, highlighting the need for a more market-based and performance-oriented system.

• OPM has taken steps to improve strategic human capital management, including finalizing revisions to its strategic human capital management regulation and developing a new Human Capital Framework.

• Agencies can drive improvements in high-risk areas, including strategic human capital management, through sustained leadership commitment, ensuring capacity, identifying root causes, monitoring actions, and demonstrating progress.

• The Global War on Terrorism (GWOT) costs fall into two main categories: military personnel and operation and maintenance.

• Military personnel funds cover pay, allowances, and special payments for all qualifying military personnel, including reservists and active-duty personnel.

• Operation and maintenance funds are used for various purposes, such as personnel and equipment transportation, unit support costs, intelligence, communications, and logistics.

• Estimating GWOT costs is challenging due to fluctuating operational requirements.

• DOD has transfer and reprogramming authorities to shift funds between accounts.

• In fiscal years 2004 and 2005, DOD received $52.4 billion and $62.1 billion, respectively, in supplemental appropriations for GWOT.

• The military services also received funds through their annual appropriations, but lost visibility over these funds.

• DOD increased its annual appropriation request by $10 billion annually starting in fiscal year 2003 to support GWOT.

• In fiscal year 2004, the Army, Air Force, and Navy received additional funds in their annual appropriations, totaling $7.9 billion.

• DOD and the military services cannot be certain that the funds were used for GWOT-related activities.

• DOD took steps to adjust the fiscal year 2005 supplemental request to reflect the receipt of funds from Program Budget Decision 736.

• The services faced gaps between reported obligations and supplemental appropriations, which they covered through transfers, reprogramming, and reducing peacetime operations.

• The Department of the Treasury (Treasury) used a process involving internal discussions and external consultations to decide to extend the Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP) and coordinate with relevant agencies. Key factors included ongoing weaknesses in housing markets, contraction in small business lending, and the need to retain resources to respond to financial instability. Treasury also considered indicators such as housing market indicators, financial market prices, and measures of program utilization.

• To improve transparency and analytical basis for program decisions, Treasury should publicly identify clear program objectives, expected impacts, and additional resources needed to meet those objectives. This includes setting quantitative objectives for small business lending programs and identifying necessary data for program decision-making.

* The Federal Meat Inspection Act, the Poultry Products Inspection Act, and the Egg Products Inspection Act assign USDA, through FSIS, responsibility for ensuring the safety of meat, poultry, and certain egg products.
* FDA, under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act and the Public Health Service Act, is responsible for all other foods, including fruits and vegetables, dairy products, seafood, and certain canned, frozen, and packaged foods.
* FDA and FSIS ensure food safety through a regulatory system of preventive controls that identifies hazards early in the production process to minimize contamination risk, using the Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Point (HACCP) system.
* The agencies inspect food facilities regularly, with FDA inspecting over 57,000 facilities every 5 years and USDA inspecting over 6,000 meat and poultry facilities daily.
* Following the 9/11 attacks, the federal government intensified efforts to protect agriculture and food products from potential terrorist attacks, leading to additional funding for FDA and FSIS to enhance security measures.

* The largest interagency contracting vehicle is the MAS program, also known as the Federal Supply Schedule or schedules program, managed by GSA.
* Government buyers often pay fees for using other agencies' GWACs, MACs, and schedule contracts, which are expected to cover administrative costs.
* Large departments like DOD and DHS are increasingly using enterprisewide contracts to acquire goods and services, which are similar to interagency contracts but generally restricted to the original acquiring activity.
* All contracts are indefinite delivery/indefinite quantity (ID/IQ) contracts, established to buy goods and services with unknown future delivery times and quantities.
* In fiscal year 2008, federal agencies spent $60 billion through GWACs, MACs, the MAS program, and enterprisewide contracts.
* The MAS program has seen relatively flat sales in recent years, while obligations under GWACs have declined slightly.
* Numerous agencies plan to increase their use of enterprisewide contracts to meet the administration's goal of reducing contracting costs by 7% through fiscal year 2011.
* GSA's MAS program is still the primary governmentwide buying program aimed at leveraging buying power for commercial goods and services.
* Interagency and enterprisewide contracts can provide advantages to government agencies, but lack of reliable data and oversight hinders effective management.
* Concerns exist about contract duplication, vendors providing similar products and services on multiple contract vehicles, and increased costs to both vendors and the government.
* Limited governmentwide policy exists for establishing and overseeing MACs and enterprisewide contracts, and recent legislation and OFPP initiatives aim to strengthen oversight of MACs but not enterprisewide contracts.

* The Internet has matured from a tool for academics and scientists to a national resource for citizens to interact with their government, receiving services, supplying and obtaining information, asking questions, and providing comments on proposed rules.
* The federal government has faced challenges with failed and troubled IT investments, such as the Office of Personnel Management's Retirement Systems Modernization program, the National Polar-orbiting Operational Environmental Satellite System, the Department of Veterans Affairs' Scheduling Replacement Project, and the Department of Health and Human Services' Healthcare.gov website.
* 18F and USDS were formed in 2014 to help address federal government IT issues. 18F, located within the Technology Transformation Service of the General Services Administration, provides services such as custom application solutions, tools for common government needs, consulting on IT acquisition and management, and education on digital services. USDS focuses on transforming the most important digital services for citizens by recruiting private sector experts to partner with government agencies.
* GAO's draft report recommends that GSA ensure goals and performance measures are outcome-oriented, establish performance measures with targets, assess actual results, and prioritize projects. GAO also recommends that OMB ensure all goals and measures are outcome-oriented, assess actual results, establish a time frame for the report on high priority programs, and update USDS policy to define the relationship between CIOs and digital services teams.

* The maturation of the baby boom generation will lead to significant changes in the ratio of the working age population to the population age 65 or older, affecting the aged dependency ratio.
* Several recent changes in Social Security retirement policy could strengthen incentives for older workers to remain employed longer, including eliminating the reduction of benefits for earnings above the normal retirement age and increasing the delayed retirement credit.
* The Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 (ADEA) promotes the employment of older persons based on ability rather than age and prohibits age discrimination in employment.
* The number of older workers will grow substantially over the next two decades, with older workers becoming a larger percentage of the total workforce.
* Employers are using various arrangements, such as rehiring retirees, reduced work schedules, and job-sharing, to retain and extend the careers of older workers, but these programs are not yet widespread in the private sector.

• The Visa Waiver Program (VWP) was created in 1986 to facilitate the legitimate travel of visitors for business or tourism to the United States from qualifying countries, aiming to boost international business, tourism, and airline revenues.

• The program's purpose is to provide visa-free travel to the United States, allowing State to allocate more resources to visa-issuing posts in countries with higher risk applicant pools.

• In 2002, the Homeland Security Act established the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and gave it responsibility for establishing visa policy, including policy for the VWP.

• In 2004, DHS created the Visa Waiver Program Oversight Unit to oversee VWP activities and monitor participating countries' adherence to program requirements.

• Since the attacks on the United States in 2001, Congress has passed laws to strengthen border security policies and procedures, including increased assessments of each country's participation in the VWP.

• To qualify for the VWP, countries must offer reciprocal visa-free travel privileges, have a low visa refusal rate, issue machine-readable passports, enter into agreements to share information on lost or stolen passports, and not compromise U.S. law enforcement or security interests.

• Travelers must have received an authorization to travel through the Electronic System for Travel Authorization (ESTA) before entering the United States, possess a valid passport, and meet other requirements.

• ESTA has added a fee and a new pretravel requirement, but DHS has taken steps to minimize the burden on VWP travelers, including reducing the requirement for biographical information and providing earlier notice of ineligibility.

• DHS has not fully analyzed the risks of carrier and passenger noncompliance with the ESTA requirement, despite carrier compliance exceeding 99% in recent years.

• Only half of the VWP countries have entered into all required information-sharing agreements with the United States, and many of these agreements have not been implemented.

• DHS has not consistently completed mandated biennial reports on each VWP country's security, law enforcement, and immigration programs and policies, which provide important information to Congress.

• The U.S. state child welfare systems are complex networks designed to protect children, facing increased demands due to growing caseloads over the past decade.

• The federal government finances foster care and sets minimum procedural requirements for the placement process, as mandated by the Adoption Assistance and Child Welfare Act of 1980.

• States must make reasonable efforts to prevent or eliminate the need for removing children from their homes and provide services to reunite them with families or find permanent placements.

• The permanency planning process involves developing a case plan for each child, reviewed every 6 months, with a permanency hearing held within 18 months.

• Children are increasingly being placed with relatives, sometimes receiving foster care subsidies.

• 26 states have enacted laws or policies to shorten the time between entering foster care and the first permanency hearing, with 23 states enacting laws and three by administrative policy.

• The federal requirement is for a permanency hearing within 18 months, but states have implemented various operational and procedural changes to expedite the process.

• Arizona's Housing Assistance Program and Kentucky's projects to expedite termination of parental rights are examples of successful initiatives.

• Concurrent planning, where child welfare officials work on reunification and permanent placement simultaneously, has been implemented in some states.

• Improving the permanency planning process requires leadership, stakeholder involvement, and resources, but many initiatives lack evaluations to assess their impact.

• The Digital Accountability and Transparency Act of 2014 (DATA Act) requires federal agencies to disclose expenditures and link agency spending information to federal program activities for policymakers and public tracking.

• The act mandates the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) and the Department of the Treasury to lead government-wide implementation, including establishing data standards and developing technical guidance.

• Challenges to data quality include internal controls over financial reporting, financial management systems, and information technology security and controls.

• Agencies face reporting challenges such as reconciling intragovernmental transactions, validating ZIP+4 information, and linking financial and award data using unique identifiers.

• The senior accountable official (SAO) assurance process leverages existing controls but raises concerns about effectiveness and reliability.

• OMB has taken steps to improve data governance, including creating a Data Standards Committee, but efforts are at an early stage.

• Risks to data quality include material weaknesses and significant deficiencies in agency audits, as well as challenges in operationalizing DATA Act policy and technical guidance.

• Agencies are making final preparations to submit data by the May 2017 deadline, but attention will focus on improving data quality and mechanisms to communicate information limitations.

• OMB and Treasury are working to address GAO's open recommendations related to DATA Act implementation, including improving data governance and providing guidance on data standards and quality assurance.

* The Office of Special Counsel (OSC) does not have in-house contracting staff and has an agreement with the Administrative Review Corporation (ARC) for contracting support.
* ARC, part of Treasury’s Bureau of the Public Debt, provides self-supporting, business-like services including contracting.
* OSC can use 5 U.S.C. § 3109 to hire intermittent consultants for expert or consultant services without competitive service provisions.
* OSC's primary mission is to protect federal employees from prohibited personnel practices, including through investigations and corrective actions.
* In contracting with MPRI for an organizational assessment, OSC did not follow required steps for competition and sole-source orders.
* ARC approved a sole-source justification for MPRI without sufficient facts or rationale, and did not question the order's validity.
* OSC officials performed duties normally done by contracting officer’s representatives without authorization or training, and ARC officials did not validate the sole-source justification.
* OSC hired an intermittent consultant, Alan J. Hicks, using 5 U.S.C. § 3109, whose tasks were consistent with OPM criteria for expert and consultant appointments.
* OSC employees face difficulties in seeking redress for prohibited personnel practices against the Special Counsel or Deputy Special Counsel due to potential conflicts of interest.
* Congress should consider providing OSC employees alternative means of addressing prohibited personnel practice allegations, such as external investigations or expanded MSPB jurisdiction.

* VA's mission is to promote the health, welfare, and dignity of veterans through medical care, benefits, social support, and memorials.
* It is the second largest federal department with offices across the U.S. and territories, and relies on three major components for its mission.
* The department's IT infrastructure supports operational needs, including data storage, transmission, and communications for benefits, health care, and other systems.
* Obsolete systems like PAID and BDN are in need of modernization or replacement, as identified in recent reports.
* VA's strategic plan for 2014 emphasizes improving access to benefits, eliminating the disability claims backlog, and ending veteran homelessness through technology.
* In fiscal year 2015, VA spent approximately $3.9 billion on IT resources, with plans for $4.1 billion in 2016 and $4.3 billion in 2017.
* VA's CIO has initiated a transformation strategy to stabilize processes, mitigate weaknesses, and improve IT management capabilities.
* Challenges include failed modernization efforts, lack of interoperability with DOD, and IT system challenges like appointment scheduling and claims processing.
* Recommendations have been made to VA to improve systems development, acquisition processes, and establish outcome-oriented goals for interoperability efforts.

• The Medicare program, managed by HCFA, serves about 33 million beneficiaries through fee-for-service and managed care options, with a high volume of claims processed annually.

• HCFA is responsible for over 400 managed care health plans serving more than 5 million beneficiaries, with enrollment growing by about 85,000 monthly.

• Medicare benefits are divided into two parts: hospital insurance (Part A) and supplementary medical insurance (Part B), covering various services and requiring payment of a monthly premium.

• HCFA, an HHS agency, has approximately 4,000 full-time employees, with most working in headquarters offices, and oversees over 60 claims processing contractors employing an estimated 22,200 people.

• Recent legislation, including the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 and the Balanced Budget Act of 1997, grants HCFA substantial authority to reform Medicare.

• HCFA is rethinking its strategy for modernizing automated claims processing and information systems, including preparing for the year 2000, repairing managed care enrollment systems, and making necessary modifications to existing systems.

• Managers are concerned about the distribution of agency resources, the need for specialized expertise, the loss of institutional experience, and reorganization issues, particularly the potential compromise of quality due to concentrated efforts on BBA implementation and year 2000 computer problems.

• Staff mix and level of skills are a concern, with a need for specialists in various areas such as computer system analysis, survey statistics, and managed care expertise.

• The reorganization, implemented in July 1997, aimed to redirect resources to managed care, acknowledge HCFA's role as a purchaser of health care services, and establish components focused on beneficiaries, health plans and providers, and Medicaid activities.

• The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is primarily funded by the Airport and Airway Trust Fund, which collects revenues from excise taxes on airline tickets, aviation fuel, and cargo. In addition, General Fund revenues are used to fund FAA, with about 18% of FAA's total appropriation coming from the General Fund in fiscal year 2006.

• The administration's reauthorization proposal would change FAA's financing system from one based mainly on excise taxes to one based more on cost-based charges. Under the proposed system, funding for Air Traffic Organization (ATO) would come primarily from user charges on commercial aircraft and fuel taxes on general aviation aircraft. Funding for Airport Improvement Program (AIP) would come from an equal fuel tax on both general and commercial aviation and a tax on arriving and departing international passengers.

• The proposal also calls for changing FAA's budget structure by establishing two new budget accounts—Air Traffic Organization and Safety and Operations—to align with FAA's lines of business and proposed funding. These two new accounts would replace the Operations and Facilities and Equipment (F&E) accounts. The proposal retains the AIP and Research, Engineering, and Development (RE&D) accounts.

* GSA's Federal Technology Service, in conjunction with the IMC, is responsible for ensuring federal agencies have access to necessary telecommunications services.
* The FTS2001 program aims to provide long-distance services, ensuring the best service and price for the government while maximizing competition.
* GSA awarded contracts to Sprint and MCI WorldCom for long-distance services, with minimum revenue guarantees and contract options extending to 2006 and 2007.
* Federal agencies spent approximately $614 million on FTS2001 services in fiscal year 2003.
* GAO has reviewed FTS2001 program development and implementation, recommending actions to facilitate transition efforts.
* GSA is planning the FTS Networx acquisition program to replace existing contracts, aiming for multiple awards to ensure best value and strong competition.
* Networx includes two acquisitions: Networx Universal for a broad range of services and Networx Select for more geographically limited services, with specific requirements yet to be defined.
* Challenges for Networx include ensuring adequate inventory information, establishing measures of success, structuring contracts for competition, and initiating smooth transition planning.
* GSA acknowledges the importance of accurate inventories and measures of success, recognizing the need for clear requirements and comprehensive program management to ensure successful transition.

* FSA, established as the government's first Performance-Based Organization (PBO) in 1998, aims to improve service in student financial assistance programs, reduce costs, increase accountability, and integrate information systems.
* FSA's performance plan discusses strategic goals to increase customer and employee satisfaction while decreasing unit cost, but lacks clarity on systems integration and program integrity measures.
* FSA has taken steps towards developing a strategic direction, including reorganizing operations, creating a management council, and implementing a balanced scorecard for performance management.
* However, gaps exist in FSA's human capital strategy, particularly in workforce planning and development, and it has not yet implemented a performance management system as required by its enabling legislation.

* The National Institutes of Health (NIH) made over 21,500 grant awards using Recovery Act funds as of September 30, 2010.
* NIH used standard review processes and criteria to award extramural scientific research grants with Recovery Act funding.
* These grants were made to three categories and varied in size, geographic distribution, duration, and research methods.
* The Recovery Act funds had to be obligated within a 2-year window (fiscal years 2009 and 2010).
* Recipients of Recovery Act funding, including NIH grantees, were required to report job support on a quarterly basis to a nationwide data collection system.
* The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) developed guidance for reporting and established internal controls for data quality.
* NIH and grantees collect information on full-time equivalents (FTEs) supported by Recovery Act funding from various sources.
* Data reported to the nationwide data collection system indicate an increase in FTEs supported by NIH Recovery Act funds from December 2009 to June 2011.
* Principal investigators reported that Recovery Act funding supported new positions, avoided reductions in employees, and allowed for part-time positions.
* NIH grantees used Recovery Act funding to purchase research supplies, equipment, and lab testing services.
* Some principal investigators reported providing scientific training to healthcare professionals through their research.
* A majority of principal investigators reported preliminary results from their Recovery Act-funded research, which could contribute to future scientific developments.
* NIH tracks scientific impacts primarily through peer-reviewed publications, and other metrics include patent applications, future grant funding, and clinical practice changes.

• The report identifies the extent of transit-oriented development near six selected transit lines that received federal funds and factors that support or hinder it.

• Factors supporting transit-oriented development include market demand for real estate, large available land for development, resident support for transit, and efficient access to jobs and centers of activity.

• Challenges to transit-oriented development are higher construction costs, lenders' reluctance to finance, lengthy approval processes, unsupportive local populations, and unattractive land features.

• Local governments can encourage transit-oriented development through zoning regulations, area plans, infrastructure investments, and tax incentives, aligning policies with local preferences and market demand.

• FTA assesses several factors related to transit-oriented development when reviewing projects for funding, including economic development effects and land use, but these account for only a small percentage of all factors considered.

• The assessment of these factors is consistent with the factors that local stakeholders identified as affecting project outcomes, though there are inherent limitations in fully evaluating some factors.

* Since the Social Security Act's inception in 1935, workers have had the right to review their earnings records at the Social Security Administration (SSA).
* In 1988, the Personal Earnings and Benefit Estimate Statement (PEBES) was introduced to enable workers to review their earnings records and obtain benefit estimates.
* SSA plans to automatically send PEBES to over 70 million workers by fiscal year 2000, aiming to inform the public about benefits, assist in financial planning, and ensure accurate earnings records.
* The PEBES includes benefit estimates based on assumptions about future employment and earnings, which may over- or understate benefits for certain individuals, such as federal workers eligible for both Civil Service Retirement System and Social Security benefits.
* SSA has conducted surveys and focus groups to assess public reaction to the unsolicited PEBES, with overall favorable responses.
* However, the PEBES provides too much information, is complex, and lacks clear layout and design, which may overwhelm readers and undermine its usefulness.
* SSA has not conducted formal comprehension tests or systematically collected detailed feedback from front-line workers to improve the statement.
* Alternative formats, such as a two-part document, have been tested, but SSA has not fully considered the most effective approach to present the information.
* Improving the layout, design, and simplifying explanations are recommended to enhance the PEBES's effectiveness in conveying information about SSA's programs and benefits.

* The Social Security Administration (SSA) administers two programs for individuals unable to work due to disability: Disability Insurance (DI) and Supplemental Security Income (SSI). Both programs use the same definition of disability for initial entitlement, but differ in eligibility requirements and funding.
* Concurrent beneficiaries, who receive benefits from both DI and SSI, are a sizable disability population. They often have mental impairments, are female, and have an average age of 45. Many concurrent beneficiaries work, with a median earned income of about $250 per month. The report recommends SSA develop procedures and guidance to ensure information about work activity is shared between DI and SSI programs, and create public information materials that explain the complex interactions of the two programs for concurrent beneficiaries.

• The federal government has provided $88 billion in emergency supplemental appropriations for Gulf Coast hurricane relief and recovery efforts since August 2005.

• FEMA, the lead agency, uses the Stafford Act to issue mission assignments to other federal agencies for disaster relief tasks.

• Agencies perform work under mission assignments, bill FEMA, and FEMA reimburses them using the Intra-Governmental Payment and Collection (IPAC) system.

• The federal government lacks mechanisms to collect and report on the use of hurricane relief funds across 23 agencies, leading to limited governmentwide perspective.

• FEMA's reports to Congress overstate obligations and understate expenditures due to differences in when agencies record obligations and FEMA records expenditures.

• Timing issues and inadequate documentation from agencies performing mission assignments result in understated expenditures in FEMA's reports.

• No central collection point exists to compile and report on the use of hurricane relief funds, hindering decision-making and accountability.

• Reporting requirements vary among agencies, and there is no framework for consolidated governmentwide reporting on hurricane-related spending.

• GAO recommends FEMA and the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) take actions to improve reporting and accountability for hurricane relief funds.

* The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has authority to authorize all Unmanned Aircraft Systems (UAS) operations in the national airspace, including military, public, and civil entities.
* Currently, FAA allows UAS access on a case-by-case basis due to the lack of a final rulemaking.
* FAA provides access through three means: Certificates of Waiver or Authorization (COA), Special Airworthiness Certificates in the Experimental Category, and Section 333 exemptions.
* FAA has approved 674 public COAs and granted 48 Section 333 exemptions since 2014.
* FAA's UAS Comprehensive Plan and Integration Roadmap outline a phased approach to integration: Accommodation, Integration, and Evolution.
* The Accommodation phase involves applying special mitigations and procedures for limited UAS access.
* The Integration phase aims to establish performance requirements for UAS to increase access to the national airspace system.
* The Evolution phase focuses on updating policies, regulations, and training to support UAS operations as the airspace evolves.
* FAA issued a Notice of Proposed Rulemaking for small UAS operations in February 2015, aiming to allow greater access once finalized.
* FAA designated six UAS test sites in 2013, which have received 48 COAs and one experimental certificate for UAS operations.
* Test sites have become operational, providing operations and safety data to FAA for UAS integration.
* FAA and test sites have worked together, with regular meetings and operational/safety process reviews.
* Other countries have regulations for commercial UAS operations, with similar requirements and restrictions.
* FAA faces challenges in issuing a final rule for small UAS operations and developing a detailed implementation plan for integration.

* The Department of Defense (DOD) has faced challenges in providing adequate management and oversight of the Commander's Emergency Response Program (CERP) in Afghanistan due to an insufficient number of trained personnel.
* CERP efforts in Afghanistan are often focused on development and construction, whereas in Iraq, the focus is on reconstructing neglected or damaged infrastructure.
* The CERP program has evolved over time, with projects becoming more complex and costing more than $500,000. In fiscal year 2008, about $281 million of the $486 million obligated was for transportation, largely for roads.
* DOD is statutorily required to provide Congress with quarterly reports on the source, allocation, and use of CERP funds. These reports are compiled based on information entered by unit officials into the Combined Information Data Network Exchange (CIDNE) database.
* DOD faces significant challenges in providing adequate management and oversight of CERP due to a lack of personnel trained to execute and manage the program. This includes issues with project oversight, training, and coordination with the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID).

• The report identifies 65 federal solar-related initiatives supported by agencies in fiscal years 2010 and 2011, focusing on research, development, and commercialization of solar technologies.

• These initiatives demonstrate a variety of key characteristics, including supporting different types of solar technologies and technology advancement activities from basic research to commercialization.

• Agencies fund solar projects through various mechanisms, primarily grants and contracts, to recipients such as universities, industry, nonprofit organizations, and federal labs.

• The Department of Energy (DOE) obligated the most funds, with over 90% of the total $2.6 billion, primarily through the Loan Guarantee Program.

• Many initiatives overlap in technology advancement activities, types of technologies, and funding recipients, but these overlaps do not necessarily lead to duplication of efforts. Coordination activities are reported to avoid duplication.

* The Department of Defense (DOD) may struggle to prevent attacks using chemical or biological weapons, necessitating protection for military personnel to ensure survival and effective operations.
* DOD supplies servicemembers with a protective ensemble including a suit, mask, boots, gloves, and hoods, but issues have been identified with the equipment's heat stress, mobility, bulkiness, and interoperability across services.
* DOD has developed new lightweight individual protective equipment, such as the Joint Service Lightweight Integrated Suit Technology (JSLIST) trousers and coat, to replace existing suits, with procurement beginning in 1997.
* The DOD's risk assessment process for chemical and biological defense is unreliable, leading to inaccurate determinations of risk, particularly in regards to protective suits, gloves, boots, and hoods.

* The report discusses the importance of program evaluations in assessing the achievement of program objectives and other aspects of performance, particularly in isolating the causal impact of programs from external conditions to assess effectiveness.
* It highlights that while most federal managers reported lacking recent evaluations of their programs in a 2013 survey, those who had evaluations found them valuable for understanding program performance, assessing effectiveness, making changes to improve management, and sharing what works with others. However, a lack of resources was cited as a barrier to implementing evaluation findings.
* The report also notes that the Government Performance and Results Act Modernization Act (GPRAMA) has established expectations for evidence to play a greater role in agency decision-making, with provisions for setting agency priority goals, conducting quarterly performance reviews, and reporting publicly on progress. The act also charges the Performance Improvement Council to facilitate the exchange of successful practices and development of tools to strengthen performance management.

* The Rehabilitation Act defines a person with a disability as having a physical or mental impairment that substantially limits one or more major life activities.
* The federal government aims to promote employment of individuals with disabilities through special hiring authorities, such as Schedule A excepted service hiring for those with intellectual, severe physical, or psychiatric disabilities.
* Executive Order 13548 commits the federal government to hiring and retaining employees with disabilities, requiring agencies to develop plans and designate senior officials accountable for meeting goals.
* Agencies track disability employment through OPM's SF-256 form, which categorizes disabilities into targeted and other, with targeted disabilities generally considered more severe.
* The federal government faces challenges in accurately measuring the number of current and newly hired employees with disabilities due to concerns about confidentiality and discrimination, affecting its ability to set and achieve employment goals.

• The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) aims to manage public lands and resources to serve American needs through its mission.

• BLM, part of the Department of the Interior, oversees about 270 million acres of public lands in 28 states, primarily in the West and Alaska.

• The agency maintains over 1 billion documents related to land surveys, patents, mining claims, and more, many of which are deteriorating.

• In the early 1980s, BLM initiated the Automated Land and Mineral Records System (ALMRS) to automate manual records and case processing.

• The project was later expanded to include a land information system (LIS) and modernization of computer and telecommunications equipment, with an estimated life-cycle cost of $880 million.

• In 1989, due to high costs, the project was scaled down to three major components: ALMRS Initial Operating Capability (ALMRS IOC), Geographic Coordinate Data Base (GCDB), and technology modernization.

• By 1993, the life-cycle cost was reduced to $403 million, and the project was designated as mission-critical to automate land and mineral records and support management activities.

• The ALMRS/Modernization project has completed most initial installations and met milestones, with tasks becoming more complex as the system is integrated and tested.

• BLM has taken actions to maintain its tight development schedule, but slippages could still occur due to little recovery time for unanticipated problems.

• BLM plans to obtain an independent assessment of the ALMRS IOC to ensure it meets requirements and provides expected support.

• BLM's stress-testing plans cover only the ALMRS IOC, not the entire modernized system, which may not provide assurance that all systems can handle peak workloads.

• The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) is an independent organization affiliated with the United Nations, responsible for implementing policies and programs related to nuclear safeguards.

• IAEA's governing bodies include the General Conference and the Board of Governors, with the Secretariat, headed by the Director General, responsible for implementing policies.

• The United States is a permanent member of the Board of Governors, and IAEA derives its authority to establish and administer safeguards from various sources including the Treaty on the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT).

• Since the NPT came into force in 1970, it has been subject to review by signatory states every 5 years, with the latest review conference occurring in May 2005.

• IAEA's safeguards objectives are to account for nuclear material necessary to produce a nuclear weapon and ensure it is not diverted from peaceful use.

• IAEA has taken steps to strengthen safeguards, including developing the capability to independently evaluate all aspects of a country's nuclear activities.

• The Nuclear Suppliers Group was established in 1975 to regulate the export of nuclear materials and equipment, requiring countries to agree to IAEA safeguards.

• IAEA has faced limitations in detecting undeclared nuclear activities, particularly in countries not subject to comprehensive safeguards agreements.

• The Nuclear Suppliers Group faces challenges including lack of complete export licensing information sharing and difficulties reaching consensus on control lists.

• The U.S. has supported efforts to secure former Soviet weapons of mass destruction assets, including through various programs to provide enhanced physical protection and radiation detection equipment.
