* The Department of Defense (DOD) relies on research laboratories, test facilities, industry, and academia to develop new technologies and systems for military operations. Historically, DOD has faced challenges in transitioning technologies from the lab to real-world use.
* DOD has established several "technology transition" programs, including the Advanced Concept Technology Demonstration (ACTD), Foreign Comparative Testing (FCT), Manufacturing Technology Program (MANTECH), and Dual Use Science and Technology program, to ease the transition and broaden participation from the industrial base. These programs collectively receive a small portion of DOD's research and development budget.
* Three newer initiatives, the Technology Transition Initiative (TTI), Defense Acquisition Challenge Program (DACP), and Quick Reaction Fund, have been implemented to speed the transition of technologies developed by DOD's Science and Technology (S&T) programs into acquisition programs. These programs have received about $64 million in fiscal year 2005, a fraction of the $9.2 billion DOD invested in applied research and advanced technology development that year.
* The transition programs have reported benefits such as improved performance, affordability, manufacturability, and operational capability for the warfighter. However, it is too early to determine the impact of these programs on technology transition. The programs lack consistent performance measures to gauge project success or track return on investment over time.

* The report assesses the reliability of schedules for two key Master Address File (MAF) development programs and examines the Census Bureau's (Bureau) adherence to leading practices for collaboration in MAF development work.
* The Bureau's schedules for Geographic Support System Initiative (GSS-I) and 2020 Research and Testing exhibit some characteristics of a reliable schedule but have important weaknesses.
* The schedules lack comprehensiveness, with missing details on activities, durations, and resource needs, and do not fully identify logic for preceding and following activities or a critical path.
* The schedules lack credibility, as they do not include a quantitative risk assessment, and there are issues with integrating management reporting and automatically updating schedules.
* The Bureau has put in place a framework for collaboration, including strategic plans, memorandums of understanding, and charters, but could improve by incorporating collaboration into schedules and ensuring staff have the necessary skills for scheduling.

• The Clean Air Act, passed in 1963, aims to improve and protect air quality in the US. It was significantly revised in 1970, 1977, and 1990.

• The 1990 amendments required EPA to establish national ambient air quality standards for pollutants, set deadlines for state implementation plans, and direct states to achieve and maintain compliance.

• EPA has set standards for pollutants like ozone, carbon monoxide, particulate matter, sulfur oxides, nitrogen dioxide, and lead.

• States are responsible for developing plans to comply with these standards, and EPA must approve these plans.

• The 1990 amendments also directed EPA to regulate hazardous air pollutants and establish a list of 189 pollutants to be controlled.

• EPA identified 452 actions required to meet the objectives of Titles I, III, and IV of the 1990 amendments.

• About half of these actions were under Title III, which includes the largest number of requirements with statutory deadlines.

• Requirements vary in scope and complexity, with some involving promulgating regulations and others requiring reports.

• Many requirements were met late, with an average delay of about 24 months for Title I, 25 months for Title III, and 15 months for Title IV.

• EPA officials cited factors like stakeholder involvement, prioritization, and competing demands for delays.

• As of April 2005, 45 of the 338 requirements with statutory deadlines related to Titles I, III, and IV had not been met.

• Most unmet requirements under Title I involve rules limiting volatile organic compound emissions from various products.

• EPA has completed most of the 452 actions required by the 1990 amendments related to Titles I, III, and IV.

• EPA's workload related to its air programs may increase due to recommendations for regulatory reform from the Office of Management and Budget.

• OJJDP established the Girls Study Group in 2004 with a $2.6 million cooperative agreement to develop research on preventing and reducing girls' delinquency.
• The group aimed to identify effective or promising programs, program elements, and implementation principles, develop program models, and address gaps in research.
• They reviewed over 1,000 documents, identified 61 programs targeting girls' delinquency, and assessed their methodological quality using DOJ's What Works criteria.
• The review process was consistent with social science research practices and standards, and OJJDP involved practitioners in the group's activities.
• The group found few studies on girls' delinquency programs, lacking conclusive evidence of effectiveness, leading to a need for additional evaluations, training, and funding.
• OJJDP plans to provide technical assistance to programs to prepare for evaluations and issue a solicitation for funding to support evaluations in fiscal year 2010.
• OJJDP has not developed a comprehensive plan for addressing girls' delinquency goals, lacking specific funding requirements, time frames, and stakeholder engagement.
• GAO recommended developing a plan that articulates responses to the Study Group's findings, includes time frames and funding commitments, and is shared with stakeholders.
• OJJDP agreed with the recommendation and outlined plans to publish a juvenile justice program plan, including addressing girls' delinquency issues, in the Federal Register for public feedback.
• The report concludes with contact information for GAO's Offices of Congressional Relations and Public Affairs.

• DOD's finance and accounting structure was reformed through the establishment of DFAS in 1991 to standardize policies, procedures, and systems.

• DFAS was created to consolidate finance and accounting operations from the military services and defense agencies, aiming to improve efficiency and oversight.

• Before 1991, each military service and defense agency had separate finance and accounting structures, leading to inefficiencies and inconsistencies.

• DFAS assumed control over large finance centers and many small offices, focusing on consolidating operations and personnel to reduce costs.

• The number of finance and accounting personnel has decreased from an estimated 46,000 in 1994 to about 40,800 in 1996, with further reductions planned.

• DOD's budget for finance and accounting activities exceeds $2 billion, with DFAS' budget at $1.64 billion in 1996.

• DFAS is responsible for reducing the number of systems used throughout DOD, aiming to standardize systems and processes.

• DOD's finance and accounting operations are divided into nine functional areas, including civilian payroll, military payroll, and accounting.

• DOD's appropriation for fiscal year 1996 was used to pay about 6 million people and process over 17 million invoices.

* The Federal Reserve Act established the Federal Reserve as an independent agency with a decentralized structure to ensure monetary policy decisions are based on a broad economic perspective from all regions of the country. The Fed's decisions are not subject to approval by the President, executive branch, or Congress.
* The Fed's monetary policy decisions are subject to oversight by Congress and aim to promote long-run objectives of maximum employment, stable prices, and moderate long-term interest rates in the U.S.
* The Federal Reserve consists of the Board of Governors, 12 Reserve Banks, and the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC). The Board of Governors, located in Washington, D.C., has broad interest in monitoring and promoting financial market stability. The Reserve Banks, which are not federal agencies, provide various services and operations, including participating in monetary policy formulation and conducting open market operations.
* The Federal Reserve Act requires member banks to purchase capital stock in their regional Reserve Bank, with a dividend rate of 6 percent. The dividend rate was intended to compensate banks for the capital they invested in the Reserve Bank and the risk associated with the new institution. The 6 percent rate was comparable to those of European central banks at the time.

* The 1992 Act aimed to address motor vehicle theft through various provisions.
* It established a task force to study problems related to theft and recommend solutions.
* The task force recommended federal legislation for uniform definitions, titling methods, and penalties.
* NHTSA surveyed states to estimate costs for implementing a national title information system.
* AAMVA planned a pilot study to evaluate the feasibility of a national titling system.
* Issues affecting implementation include concerns about uniformity, funding, and responsibility for the titling system.
* NHTSA issued regulations for marking major component parts of passenger vehicles in two phases.
* The Attorney General is to determine the effectiveness of the marking program.
* NSPMVIS, operated by NICB, was established to check vehicle theft status, but faces funding and implementation challenges.
* The system's effectiveness is addressed in ongoing NHTSA studies and requires law enforcement cooperation.

* The distribution of and payment for prescription drugs involve interactions among multiple entities including wholesalers, independent pharmacies, PSAOs, and third-party payers.
* Wholesalers purchase bulk quantities of drugs from manufacturers and distribute them to pharmacies, including independent ones, which account for over 15% of total sales.
* Independent pharmacies, often located in rural and underserved areas, primarily purchase drugs from wholesalers and represent a significant part of a wholesaler's customer portfolio.
* PSAOs negotiate contracts on behalf of independent pharmacies with third-party payers or their PBMs, significantly affecting the financial viability of these pharmacies.
* Third-party payers, accounting for almost 80% of drug expenditures, include private and public health plans managed by PBMs.
* PSAOs provide a range of services to independent pharmacies, including contract negotiation, communication, and help-desk services, aiming to achieve administrative efficiencies.
* PSAOs vary in their requirements for member pharmacies, with some requiring participation in all contracts negotiated by the PSAO.
* PSAOs serve as a communication link between member pharmacies and third-party payers, providing information on contractual and regulatory requirements.
* PSAOs offer services intended to create administrative and cost efficiencies for both independent pharmacies and third-party payers, potentially reducing PBMs' call center volume.

* The report assesses the current status of 27 major federal department and agency enterprise architecture efforts, focusing on 28 programs across these entities. It evaluates the programs against a maturity framework with 31 core elements across governance, content, use, and measurement.
* The analysis reveals wide variability in the maturity of these architecture programs, with most agencies having satisfied a significant portion of the core elements but still facing challenges in fully implementing enterprise architecture management. The report highlights the importance of sustained leadership and the need for agencies to address challenges such as organizational parochialism, funding, skilled staff, and executive understanding to realize the benefits of enterprise architectures.

* The U.S.-Oman Free Trade Agreement (FTA) was concluded on October 13, 2005, and signed on January 19, 2006. It is the fifth U.S. bilateral FTA with a Middle East country and aims to support Middle East economic growth and democracy through trade.
* Oman, a small oil-exporting country strategically located at the entrance to the Persian Gulf, sought to liberalize and diversify its trade regime to broaden economic opportunities for its growing workforce. The FTA with the U.S. is part of Oman's strategy to expand its economy beyond oil and gas exports.

• Hate crimes are defined as criminal offenses motivated by bias against various groups.
• Congress has enacted laws to address hate crimes, including the Civil Rights Act of 1968, the Hate Crimes Statistics Act of 1990, and the Hate Crimes Sentencing Enhancement Act of 1994.
• The Matthew Shepard and James Byrd, Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act of 2009 expanded the scope of hate crimes to include gender, sexual orientation, gender identity, and disability.
• The United States Supreme Court's decision in United States v. Morrison questioned Congress's authority to expand hate crimes legislation under the commerce clause.
• Congress's authority to proscribe hate crimes and enact civil rights legislation is discussed in relation to the commerce clause, section 5 of the 14th Amendment, and section 2 of the 13th and 15th Amendments.
• The commerce clause allows Congress to regulate activities that substantially affect interstate commerce, but the Court narrowed this category in Morrison.
• Section 5 of the 14th Amendment grants Congress the power to enforce the Amendment's provisions, but it applies to state action, not private actions.
• Section 2 of the 13th Amendment, which abolishes slavery and involuntary servitude, may be a more viable option for broadening hate crime legislation, but its scope is unclear.
• Hate crime legislation faces constitutional challenges under the 1st and 6th Amendments, particularly regarding the protection of free speech and the right to a jury trial.

• The exchange rate policies of East Asian nations, particularly China, Japan, and South Korea, have been a source of tension with the United States due to concerns over currency manipulation aimed at keeping exports price-competitive.

• The Trade Facilitation and Trade Enforcement Act of 2015 requires the Department of the Treasury to analyze and report on the macroeconomic and currency exchange rate policies of major trading partners, including those with significant bilateral trade surpluses, material current account surpluses, and persistent one-sided foreign exchange market interventions.

• East Asian governments often opt for managed float exchange rate policies, which allow for some autonomy in monetary policy while managing currency values to support economic goals.

• The categorization of exchange rate policies can be complex, especially during financial crises, as seen during the 2008 global financial crisis, when South Korea and China's policies were subject to scrutiny.

• The renminbi's value relative to the U.S. dollar has been a focal point, with China's central bank adjusting the crawling peg policy in response to global economic conditions.

• Japan's yen has shown significant fluctuations against the U.S. dollar, influenced by factors such as fiscal and monetary policies aimed at stimulating economic growth, though some U.S. business leaders have alleged government intervention to weaken the yen.

• The existence of a "renminbi bloc" in Southeast Asia, characterized by coordinated movements in exchange rates relative to China's renminbi, has been observed, though its dynamics have evolved over time.

• The Department of the Treasury has been required to report on foreign exchange rate policies since 1988, with past reports identifying countries like South Korea and Taiwan for currency manipulation under specific criteria.

• The Currency Reform for Fair Trade Act proposes imposing countervailing duties on imports from countries with fundamentally undervalued currencies, based on criteria including large-scale foreign exchange market interventions and significant current account surpluses.

* The Chief of Mission (COM) is the principal officer in charge of U.S. diplomatic missions abroad, usually an ambassador leading U.S. embassies, but also other diplomatic personnel.
* COMs are appointed by the President with Senate confirmation, serving as the President's personal representative with oversight of U.S. government activities in their country of assignment.
* The role of COMs has expanded since World War II, particularly with the postwar expansion of U.S. foreign assistance, requiring coordination of nearly all U.S. government activities in their country of assignment.
* COMs are responsible for the direction, coordination, and supervision of all U.S. government executive branch employees in their country, except for Voice of America correspondents and personnel under a U.S. Geographic Combatant Commander.
* COMs are tasked with keeping themselves fully informed of all U.S. government activities in their country and ensuring compliance with directives.
* COMs have authority over all executive branch agency personnel in their country, but not over legislative or judicial branch representatives.
* COM authority is derived from the President's constitutional powers in foreign affairs, as well as executive orders and State Department regulations.
* The State Department's 2010 Quadrennial Diplomacy and Development Review emphasizes the role of COMs as CEOs of multi-agency missions, leading and overseeing civilians from multiple federal agencies.
* Congress plays a role in selecting COMs, providing resources, and overseeing their conduct of missions.
* Concerns about the effectiveness of COM authority in practice and ways to improve it include training, education, and support from the State Department.

* China's economy heavily relies on global trade and investment, becoming the world's second-largest merchandise exporter in 2007.
* Net exports contributed significantly to China's GDP growth in 2007, with exports as a share of GDP rising from 9.1% in 1985 to 37.8% in 2008.
* Foreign direct investment (FDI) has been a major driver of productivity gains and economic growth in China.
* The global economic slowdown, particularly in major export markets, negatively impacted China's export sector and FDI flows.
* China's economy slowed significantly in 2008 and early 2009, with real GDP growth rates declining to 6.8% and 6.1% respectively.
* Annual economic growth below 8% could lead to social unrest in China, given the high number of people seeking jobs annually.
* China was the single most important contributor to world economic growth in 2007, making its economic slowdown or recovery significant globally.
* The extent of China's exposure to the global financial crisis, especially from the U.S. sub-prime mortgage problem, is unclear due to capital flow restrictions.

• The national mining and minerals policy fosters private enterprise in the development of domestic mining, minerals, and mineral reclamation industries to help assure satisfaction of industrial, security, and environmental needs.

• The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) manages most federal mineral development and is responsible for implementing the national mining and minerals policy.

• Federal land in the National Forest System (NFS) is under the jurisdiction of the Forest Service, which plays a role in authorizing mineral development on NFS lands.

• The MLLA authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to lease oil and gas deposits and onshore public domain lands containing oil and gas deposits, with the federal government retaining title to the lands.

• The Secretary of the Interior cannot issue any lease for NFS lands reserved from the public domain if the Secretary of Agriculture objects.

• The U.S. Forest Service has issued separate regulations governing certain aspects of leasing and permitting for oil and gas development on lands within its jurisdiction.

• The MLLA authorizes both competitive and noncompetitive leasing procedures, with the competitive process being the usual first step.

• NEPA applies to the competitive and noncompetitive leasing processes, possibly requiring preparation of a supplemental EIS (SEIS) or a new EA or EIS, unless reliance on old documents is sufficient or the agency issues a FONSI.

• The 2005 Energy Policy Act (EPACT) requires the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture to enter into a memorandum of understanding regarding issues such as the establishment of procedures to ensure timely processing of oil and gas lease applications, surface use plans of operation, and APDs.

* The report analyzes data from the Internal Revenue Service's (IRS) Statistics of Income to provide an overview of who claims itemized deductions, what they claim them for, and the amount in deductions claimed. It also presents the revenue loss associated with several of the larger deductions using data from the Joint Committee on Taxation's (JCT) tax expenditure estimates.
* In 2014, 30% of all tax filers chose to itemize their deductions, with higher-income individuals choosing to do so more often than lower-income individuals. The share of tax filers who chose to itemize in income ranges above $200,000 remained virtually the same (over 90%), although the average sum of itemized deductions claimed increases substantially as income rises.
* Tax filers in different income ranges tended to claim specific itemized deductions in different frequencies. For example, the deduction for charitable gifts was claimed by a higher percentage of tax filers with an AGI between $50,000 and $100,000, $100,000 and $200,000, and each of the income ranges over $200,000 compared to lower-income ranges.
* The home mortgage interest deduction comprised the largest share of total itemized deductions for itemizers with an AGI between $20,000 and $200,000, while the deduction for state and local income taxes comprised the largest share of total itemized deductions for itemizers with an AGI greater than $200,000.

• The Pacific Islands region, encompassing 14 sovereign states and territories, presents Congress with a range of policy issues, including strategic importance, economic development, climate change, and foreign aid.

• The United States, Australia, New Zealand, and France maintain spheres of influence in the region. The U.S. focuses on the Micronesian and Polynesian subregions, including territories and Freely Associated States.

• China has become a significant diplomatic and economic actor in the region, providing substantial foreign assistance and engaging in trade, but Australia remains the leading aid donor.

• Climate change is a major concern, with Pacific Island countries vulnerable to rising sea levels, ocean acidification, and extreme weather events. The region is also grappling with environmental issues like invasive species and fisheries poaching.

* The Endangered Species Act (ESA) provides for the listing and protection of species that are endangered or threatened with extinction, with limitations on activities affecting those species and penalties for taking individuals of a listed species.
* Federal agencies are required to consult with the Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) or the National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS) to determine if their actions might jeopardize listed species or destroy or adversely modify their critical habitats.
* If a project could jeopardize a species, a jeopardy opinion is released along with reasonable and prudent alternatives (RPAs) to avoid jeopardy. An incidental take statement is issued, including reasonable and prudent measures (RPMs) to minimize project effects.
* When a federal action cannot be conducted without jeopardizing species, and the federal agency believes that RPAs would thwart the project, the agency, governor, or license/permit applicant may seek an exemption. The exemption process is rarely used, with only two instances of granted exemptions in over four decades since the ESA was enacted.
* The exemption process involves a committee of top government officials who balance the national interest in protecting listed species against the national interest in proceeding with a federal project. The process includes fact-finding, hearings, and a report by the Secretary of the Interior, with the committee determining whether to grant an exemption based on criteria including the availability of reasonable alternatives and the benefits of the action.

• The current income tax treatment of capital gains and losses involves a multi-step process where short-term capital losses are deducted from short-term capital gains, followed by long-term capital losses from long-term gains. The net short-term and long-term gains or losses are then combined, and if a net loss is produced, it is deductible against other types of income up to a $3,000 annual limit. Excess losses can be carried forward indefinitely.

• Historically, the treatment of capital gains and losses has evolved significantly, with changes aimed at addressing inconsistencies and asymmetries in the tax system. Key legislative changes include the introduction of short and long-term asset classifications, limits on the deductibility of capital losses, and adjustments to tax rates and loss carryovers. The focus has been on balancing the tax treatment of gains and losses while addressing the ability of taxpayers to manipulate their tax liabilities through the timing of gains and losses realization.

* The National Labor Relations Act (NLRA) recognizes the right of employees to engage in collective bargaining through representatives of their choosing.
* The right to engage in collective bargaining under the NLRA does not apply to all individuals employed by an employer; rather, it extends only to "employees."
* An employee's job title does not determine whether an individual is a supervisor for purposes of the NLRA; instead, the term "supervisor" is defined by the Act to include any individual with the authority to perform any one of 12 specified functions, if the exercise of such authority requires the use of independent judgment and is not merely routine or clerical.
* The NLRB and U.S. Supreme Court have sought to provide meaning to the term "independent judgment" in section 2(11) of the NLRA.
* In NLRB v. Kentucky River Community Care, Inc., the Court considered whether certain nurses should be classified as supervisors for purposes of the NLRA when their judgment was informed by professional or technical training or experience.
* In Oakwood Healthcare, Inc., the NLRB revisited the issue of supervisory status, defining the terms "assign," "responsibly to direct," and "independent judgment" as they are used in section 2(11) of the NLRA.
* Section 8(a)(1) of the NLRA prohibits employers from interfering with, restraining, or coercing employees in the exercise of their rights guaranteed in section 7.
* Section 8(b)(1)(A) of the NLRA prohibits labor organizations or their agents from restraining or coercing employees in the exercise of their rights guaranteed in section 7.
* The NLRB has indicated that section 8(b)(1)(A) "broadly interdicts any union conduct threatening job security of employees because of the employees' refusal or failure to abide by union membership conditions."

* Banks play a central role in the financial system by connecting borrowers to savers and allocating capital across the economy, which is vital to the health and growth of the U.S. economy.
* Banking is inherently risky, involving extending credit and taking on liabilities. This risk can lead to banking panics and failures, which can cause large losses and systemic stress.
* Prudential regulation, including capital ratio requirements and restrictions on permissible activities, is designed to ensure banks are safely profitable and reduce the risk of failure.
* The regulatory system has evolved over time, with changes made in response to perceived weaknesses in the financial regulatory system, particularly after the 2008-2009 financial crisis.
* Issues related to banking include the balance between regulatory burden and credit availability, the role of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau in consumer protection, the "too big to fail" problem, and the long-term decline in the number of community banks.

* The Medicare, Medicaid, and SCHIP Extension Act of 2007 was signed into law on December 29, 2007.
* It made changes to the nation's three major health programs: Medicare, Medicaid, and the State Children's Health Insurance Program (SCHIP).
* The Act suspended the scheduled Medicare physician payment cut and provided SCHIP funding through March 2009.
* It redistributed any unspent FY2006 funds to states projected to exhaust their SCHIP funds in FY2009.
* The Act extended the Physician Quality Reporting System for physicians and other health care professionals under Medicare.
* It allowed Medicare Special Needs Plans to continue to restrict enrollment until January 1, 2010.
* The Act extended cost-based Medicare plans' operation in areas with two local or two regional MA plans until January 1, 2009.
* It provided up to $1.6 billion to shortfall states for FY2008 and additional sums for territories.
* The Act extended expiring provisions and programs affecting Medicare plans and providers, Medicaid payments, and miscellaneous activities.

* The House of Representatives' standing rules, primarily found in Rules XI and XIII, govern the powers, authority, activities, and operations of its committees. These rules cover areas such as committee establishment, assignments, hearings, markups, reporting, oversight, investigations, funding, staff, travel, and other duties.
* Key provisions include the requirement for committees to adopt written rules that cannot be inconsistent with House rules, the obligation to report activities at the end of each Congress, and the necessity to maintain separate records from the personal office records of the committee chair. Committees are also tasked with continually overseeing the application and effectiveness of laws and programs within their jurisdictions, conducting studies and investigations, and ensuring fair treatment of minority staff.

* The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is a 10-member grouping with a combined population of 580 million and an annual GDP of around $1.5 trillion, fostering regional dialogue and representing a strategically and economically important region.
* The Obama Administration has pursued a policy of expanding and upgrading U.S. relations with Southeast Asia, including with ASEAN, to address issues like maritime security, democracy, trade, and counterterrorism.
* ASEAN's symbolic and substantive moves, such as Secretary of State Clinton's visits and the U.S.-ASEAN leaders' meeting, suggest a higher level of engagement and persistence from the U.S.
* ASEAN's strategic value lies in its geographic position and economic development, making it a key player in regional security and trade architectures, but faces challenges balancing external actors and maintaining its role.
* ASEAN-China relations have deepened, with China engaging in a "charm offensive" and becoming a significant source of aid, trade, and influence in the region, leading to concerns about a potential power imbalance.
* The U.S. exerts the most established military presence in the region, including alliances and security cooperation, while also engaging economically, with ASEAN being the fourth-largest trading partner for the U.S.

* The "state sponsors of terrorism list" is mandated under Section 6(j) of the Export Administration Act of 1979, which requires the Secretary of State to determine if a country "has repeatedly provided support for acts of international terrorism."
* Cuba has been on the list since 1982, alongside Iran, North Korea, Sudan, and Syria. Restrictions on trade, foreign aid, and international financial institutions apply to these countries.
* Being on the terrorism list requires validated licenses for exports to these countries, except for certain items like informational materials, humanitarian assistance, and food and medicine.
* Cuba's retention on the list has received increased attention due to legislative initiatives to lift U.S. economic sanctions under the current embargo.
* Sanctions have not been removed, and Cuba remains subject to a comprehensive U.S. trade and financial embargo.
* Section 6(j) allows for a country's removal from the terrorism list if the President certifies a fundamental change in leadership, no support for terrorism, and future assurances.
* Over the years, three countries—South Yemen, Iraq, and Libya—have been removed from the list.
* The Reagan Administration added Cuba to the list in 1982 based on allegations of ties to international terrorism, including support for armed insurgencies and terrorist activities in Latin America.
* The State Department maintains that Cuba continues to support terrorist groups in Latin America, including the FALN, FMLN, and FSLN, and has provided safe haven for members of these and other organizations.
* The 2005 State Department report acknowledged Cuba's opposition to the U.S.-led global war on terror, lack of counterterrorism efforts, and close relationships with other state sponsors of terrorism.

• The Alternative Minimum Tax (AMT) is a tax calculation that uses a broader tax base than the regular tax, adding back various provisions such as business provisions, certain itemized deductions, and personal exemptions. 
• The AMT applies a progressive tax rate structure, with the first $175,000 taxed at 26% and the remainder at 28%, with exemptions phased out. 
• The AMT's base is broader than the regular tax base, but excludes certain provisions like lower capital gains tax rates and exclusions for tax-exempt bonds. 
• The number of taxpayers subject to the AMT has increased significantly over time, due to inflation and changes in tax laws, and is projected to continue growing. 
• The cost of correcting the AMT, such as by indexing exemptions for inflation, is substantial, estimated to be $13.9 billion by 2008, and could be higher with recent tax changes.

• The THUD Appropriations Subcommittees in the House and Senate are responsible for drafting bills to provide annual appropriations for the Department of Transportation (DOT), the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD), and six small related agencies. Title I funds DOT, which is primarily a grant-making and regulatory organization responsible for infrastructure and safety in various modes of transportation. Title II funds HUD, which addresses housing problems for low-income households and those with special needs through rental assistance programs and block grants. Title III funds agencies involved in transportation or housing and community development, including the Surface Transportation Board, which was made independent of DOT in 2015 legislation.

• The THUD bill typically includes regular annual appropriations, which are discretionary budget allocations made each year by the appropriations committees, and contract authority, a form of mandatory budget authority based on federal trust fund resources. The Trump Administration's FY2018 budget requested a $106.65 billion funding level for the THUD bill, $9.7 billion less than the FY2017 funding level. The House-passed bill would provide $115.3 billion, while the Senate-reported bill recommended $119.1 billion, representing slight increases over FY2017 funding.

• The THUD bill includes funding for various programs and activities, such as transportation infrastructure, housing assistance, and community development. The bill also includes general provisions applicable to the bill, which can range from restrictions on funding to supplemental funding for disasters. The funding for the THUD bill is typically offset by rescissions and offsets, such as budgetary savings from HUD's Federal Housing Administration insurance fund, which can vary from year to year.

* A July 2005 Joint Statement established a U.S.-India "global partnership" through increased cooperation on economic issues, energy, environment, democracy, development, non-proliferation, security, and high-technology.
* India-Iran relations have traditionally been positive, with the two countries launching a "strategic partnership" in January 2003, and Indian leaders speaking of "civilizational ties" between the two countries.
* Some in Washington believe that New Delhi's friendship with Tehran could become a significant obstacle to further development of U.S.-India ties, but India-Iran relations have not evolved into a strategic alliance.
* There are concerns in Congress about India's relations with Iran and their relevance to U.S. interests, particularly regarding defense relations, energy commerce, and the proposed gas pipeline to India through Pakistan.
* India's main opposition, the Bharatiya Janata Party, has voiced approval of the present government's policy toward Iran's nuclear program, while the current Indian National Congress-led coalition government has sought to maintain a careful balance between two sometimes conflicting policy objectives.

• The source document discusses the potential for imposing new import barriers on milk protein concentrates (MPCs) in the United States, which are derived from raw milk and used in various food products, animal feed, and industrial products. Advocates argue that such barriers would encourage the use of domestically produced protein and raise milk prices for dairy farmers, while opponents contend that it would increase their costs and lead to higher retail food prices.

• The document also outlines the potential consequences of such import restrictions, including the likelihood of compensation negotiations with major foreign suppliers under World Trade Organization (WTO) rules, and the impact on U.S. dairy farmers' financial situation. It further explains the current status of imports, suppliers, and the legislative history of proposed import restrictions, including the proposed legislation's potential effects on trade and compensation negotiations.

* In October 2000, a coalition of democratic parties defeated Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic in presidential elections, marking a transition towards Western democratic and free market standards.
* Serbia has held largely free and fair elections, with a new constitution adopted in 2006. However, the global economic crisis has dealt a setback to the economy.
* Organized crime and high-level corruption remain significant issues, and Serbia has set integration in the European Union as its key foreign policy goal.
* The country's most recent parliamentary, presidential, and local elections were held on May 6, 2012, with the nationalist Serbian Progressive Party winning the majority of seats.
* The powers of the Serbian presidency are modest, but the presence of the Progressives in the government will likely strengthen his hand.
* The continuing economic crisis in Serbia remains the key problem for the government, with the government boosting its popularity by launching an anti-corruption drive.
* Serbia's relations with its former Kosovo province have been a challenge, with the EU-brokered dialogue aiming to normalize relations and Serbia's EU membership prospects clouded by the issue of Kosovo.

* The Supreme Court decided four search and seizure cases during its October 2012 term, including Florida v. Jardines, Florida v. Harris, Bailey v. United States, and Missouri v. McNeely.
* In Florida v. Jardines, the Court held that a trained narcotics-detection dog's sniff at the front door of a suspected marijuana grow house is a Fourth Amendment search requiring probable cause.
* In Florida v. Harris, the Court affirmed that a trained drug-detection dog's alert is insufficient to establish probable cause for a search of a vehicle.
* In Bailey v. United States, the Court ruled that under the Michigan v. Summer's rule, the detention of an individual who has just left the premises to be searched under warrant is permissible when the individual is detained out of view of the house as soon as practicable.
* In Missouri v. McNeely, the Court held that the natural metabolization of alcohol in the bloodstream does not present a per se exigency that justifies an exception to the Fourth Amendment's warrant requirement for nonconsensual blood testing in all drunk-driving cases.

• The federal government first supported a program for energy storage and electric power system technology during the 1970s, before the establishment of the Department of Energy (DOE).

• The program was initially focused on energy storage, particularly to stabilize the variable power production from growing wind and solar technologies, and also to support large coal and nuclear power plants.

• The advancement of computer capacity, miniaturization, and industrial controls has expanded the ability of grid operators to monitor and control electric power flows.

• The subsequent increase in networking of computerized devices for grid data collection and control has advanced the ability of operators to anticipate, avoid, and mitigate potential power crises.

• Internet-connected networks have become vulnerable to unwanted computer-driven intrusions and disruptions, revealing a new cybersecurity challenge for electric power systems.

• The nation's energy infrastructure is diverse, including a variety of transmission and distribution system network structures, operating models, and hardware and software.

• The energy sector consists of thousands of electricity, oil, and natural gas assets that are dispersed geographically, leading to significant interdependency within the sector and across the nation's critical energy infrastructure sectors.

• The DOE Office of Electricity Delivery and Energy Reliability (OE) is charged with supporting more economically competitive, environmentally responsible, secure, and resilient U.S. energy infrastructure.

• OE supports electric grid modernization and resiliency through research and development, demonstration projects, partnerships, facilitation, modeling and analytics, and emergency preparedness and response.

• The FY2017 OE request aimed to support the Obama Administration's "all-of-the-above" energy strategy, emphasizing priorities that increase electric grid resilience.

* The Commemorative Works Act (CWA) was enacted in 1986 to guide the creation of memorials in the District of Columbia.
* Prior to 1986, there were no statutory criteria for authorizing commemorative works, including memorials.
* The CWA established how sponsoring organizations could choose site locations and approve memorial designs.
* Special memorial commissions were sometimes established to select memorial locations.
* Congress authorized private organizations to select sites, with the President's approval in some cases.
* The CWA was enacted in response to the need for a statutory process for memorial creation.
* The McMillan Plan, developed in 1901, influenced the CWA's goal to restore unity in memorial design.
* The CWA defines a commemorative work as any structure or landscape feature designed to perpetuate memory.
* The CWA does not apply to military properties, the Smithsonian, or the Architect of the Capitol.
* The CWA was amended in 1991 to extend the time for completing memorials from five to seven years.

* The Senate Finance Committee approved the America's Healthy Future Act of 2009, which aimed to reform the private health insurance market.
* The act included provisions for an individual mandate requiring most individuals to maintain health insurance, with penalties for noncompliance.
* Employers with over 50 full-time employees were required to offer health insurance or pay a tax, with exceptions.
* The bill established new health insurance plans, including qualified health benefits plans (QHBPs) and qualified basic health plans (QBHPs).
* It simplified the private health insurance market by applying federal standards related to risk allocation, rating reforms, and essential benefits.
* The bill required insurers to offer QHBPs on a guaranteed issue and renewal basis, and prohibited pre-existing condition exclusions.
* It introduced a system of exchanges where individuals and small businesses could access QHBPs, with separate exchanges for individuals and small employers.
* Premium subsidies were provided to eligible individuals to help pay for health insurance premiums and cost-sharing.
* The bill incentivized the creation of health insurance cooperatives through a $6 billion CO-OP program.
* Revenue provisions in Title VI included excise taxes on health insurers, limitations on executive compensation, and adjustments to tax-advantaged accounts and deductions.

• High risk health insurance pools, established in 35 states, target individuals unable to obtain or afford health insurance due to preexisting health conditions.
• These pools aim to provide coverage for those denied or priced out of the private market, aligning with the portability and guaranteed availability provisions of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (HIPAA).
• Enrollment in state high risk pools is limited, with approximately 200,000 individuals enrolled in 2008, despite nearly 4 million potentially eligible persons.
• The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) established a temporary high risk pool program to provide coverage to individuals with preexisting health conditions who have been uninsured for six or more months, effective prior to 2014.
• Federal grants to state high risk pools have been provided through various legislative acts, with funding used to support the creation, implementation, and operation of these pools, aiming to reduce the number of uninsured individuals.

* The Civil Reserve Air Fleet (CRAF) was established by President Truman in 1951 to meet the nation's airlift needs in times of crisis. It is managed by the Department of Defense (DOD) and the Department of Transportation (DOT), with DOD and DOT working together to oversee the program. CRAF supports DOD airlift requirements in emergencies when the need for airlift exceeds the capacity of DOD's organic airlift fleet.
* CRAF has three main segments: international, national, and aeromedical evacuation. The international segment is further divided into long-range and short-range sections, while the national segment is divided into domestic and Alaskan sections. The program has been formally activated twice, during Operations Desert Shield/Storm and Iraqi Freedom, with the latter lasting from February 8, 2003, to June 18, 2003. As of March 2008, 35 carriers with 1,262 aircraft were enrolled in the CRAF.
* CRAF presents benefits and opportunities for both the DOD and the U.S. airline industry, with the primary benefit being its relatively low cost compared to procuring and maintaining a larger organic fleet. However, commercial aircraft have operational limitations when compared to DOD's organic airlift fleet, such as not being able to carry outsized cargo or conduct special missions. The program's future may be affected by changes in DOD's strategic airlift requirements and air mobility force structure, as well as potential changes in economic and financial conditions for commercial air carriers.

* The National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) is an agency within the U.S. Department of Commerce that serves as the executive branch's principal advisory office on domestic and international telecommunications and information technology policies.
* The NTIA collaborates with other executive branch agencies to develop and present the Administration's position on key policy matters, representing the executive branch in both domestic and international telecommunications and information policy activities.
* The NTIA administers grant programs such as the Broadband Technology Opportunities Program (BTOP) and the Public Safety Interoperable Communications (PSIC) grant program, and is responsible for overseeing the transfer of some radio frequencies from the federal domain to the commercial domain.
* The NTIA supports the Administration's policy goal of increasing spectrum capacity for mobile broadband by 500 MHz, through various initiatives including clearing federal users from designated frequencies, sharing federal frequencies with specific commercial users, and improving the efficiency of federal spectrum use and management.

• The Energy Policy Act of 2005 (P.L. 109-58) was the first omnibus energy legislation enacted in over a decade, focusing on tax incentives for domestic energy production, doubling the nation's use of biofuels, faster procedures for energy production on federal lands, and authorization of numerous federal energy research and development programs.

• The Electric Reliability Act of 2005, subtitle of the Energy Policy Act, aims to provide federal jurisdiction over activities supporting the reliability of the U.S. bulk power system. It clarifies the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission's (FERC) authority to establish and regulate an electric reliability organization (ERO) to improve reliability as the U.S. bulk power system undergoes restructuring.

• The act requires FERC to promulgate rules within 180 days of enactment to create a FERC-certified ERO, which will develop and enforce reliability standards for the bulk power system, including cybersecurity protection. All ERO standards must be approved by FERC, and the ERO can impose penalties on users, owners, or operators of a bulk power system that violate any FERC-approved reliability standard.

• The act establishes a regional advisory body if requested by at least two-thirds of the states within a region that have more than half of their electric load served within that region. The advisory body will be composed of one member from each participating state, appointed by the governor of each state, and will provide advice to the ERO or FERC on reliability standards, proposed regional entities, proposed fees, and any other responsibilities requested by FERC.

• The act does not apply to Alaska or Hawaii, and the state of New York is authorized to develop rules that would result in greater reliability for New York, as long as those rules do not result in lower reliability for neighboring states.

• The Robinson-Patman Act (R-P) was enacted in 1936 to ensure small businesses could compete effectively with larger rivals in purchasing commodities.
• It prohibits sellers in interstate commerce from charging different purchasers different prices for goods of "like grade and quality," with exceptions for nonprofit institutions and meeting competition.
• The act has faced criticism from the Department of Justice, which believes it is not beneficial to consumers.
• The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) is responsible for enforcing the act, but its actions have been inconsistent.
• The act includes defenses such as meeting competition and cost justification, and an exemption for nonprofit institutions under the Nonprofit Institutions Act.
• The Supreme Court has interpreted the Nonprofit Institutions Act to limit the Robinson-Patman exemption for nonprofit hospitals and health maintenance organizations (HMOs).
• If none of the affirmative defenses justify a challenged price differential, and the nonprofit exemption is unavailable, price discrimination in violation of the Robinson-Patman Act is proved.
• The successful plaintiff is entitled to damages in the amount of the unlawful price differential, but this is not a foregone conclusion.
• The act has faced calls for amendment or repeal, with the Antitrust Modernization Commission recommending its repeal in 2007.

• The Obama Administration has faced scrutiny for nonenforcement, under enforcement, or delayed enforcement of federal laws through stated agency policies.
• These decisions have generally been implemented to prioritize certain federal priorities over specific provisions of federal law, particularly in the context of marijuana legalization and the Affordable Care Act.
• The Department of Justice (DOJ) has cited prosecutorial discretion as the basis for its efforts to curtail enforcement of the Controlled Substances Act in states with medical and recreational marijuana legalization.
• The Secretary of Homeland Security relied on administrative enforcement discretion in a memorandum to prioritize deportation cases against specific class of individuals who entered the U.S. as children.
• The Administration utilized enforcement discretion to justify delays in enforcing provisions of the Affordable Care Act, including the employer mandate and minimum coverage requirements.
• Some Members of Congress have argued that these unilateral Presidential nonenforcement determinations upset the separation of powers and are in direct violation of the President's constitutional obligation to "take care that the laws be faithfully executed."
• The House has approved legislation that would require the Administration to provide Congress with a report describing the legal grounds for any nonenforcement decisions.
• The ENFORCE the Law Act of 2014 would establish an expedited process for Congress to challenge nonenforcement policies.
• The Take Care Clause of the Constitution imposes an obligation on the President to ensure that laws are faithfully executed, but also provides discretion in the enforcement of laws.
• The judicial branch traditionally does not review discretionary enforcement decisions, including the decision to initiate a criminal prosecution or administrative enforcement action.
• Congress has authority to restrict executive discretion in the enforcement of federal law by explicitly guiding or restricting the exercise of that discretion through statute.

• In 2013, the official U.S. poverty rate was 14.5%, marking the first statistically significant drop since 2006, with 45.3 million persons estimated to be below the poverty line.

• Poverty rates closely follow economic cycles, rising during recessions and falling during economic growth. The rate increased over the past decade, partly due to two recessions.

• The poverty rate for non-aged adults reached 13.8% in 2010, the highest since the early 1960s. In 2013, it remained unchanged at 13.6%.

• The poverty rate for children fell from 2012 to 2013, with an estimated 1.3 million fewer children living in poverty. However, the rate (19.5%) is still above the pre-recession level.

• The poverty rate for the aged (9.5%) was unchanged from 2012, but the number of aged poor rose by 305,000.

• The Census Bureau's poverty thresholds, used to estimate poverty, are based on living standards from the mid-1950s and do not adjust for changes in living standards over time.

• Poverty is concentrated among minorities, women and children, the very old, the unemployed, and those with low education, skills, or disability.

• The Supplemental Poverty Measure (SPM) was released in 2014 to address flaws in the official measure, including the inclusion of in-kind benefits and necessary expenses.

* The U.S. agricultural sector heavily relies on trade, with exports accounting for about 20% of total U.S. agricultural production.
* The omnibus U.S. farm legislation, known as the farm bill, is renewed every five to six years, with provisions for income and commodity price support programs dating back to the 1930s.
* The current farm bill, the Agricultural Act of 2014, made substantial changes to previous farm safety net programs, with most provisions lasting until September 30, 2018.
* The U.S. is subject to a spending limit of $19.1 billion in amber box outlays, with certain de minimis exclusions applying.
* Green box policies, which are presumed to have minimal trade-distorting effects, are not counted towards the AMS limit.
* Blue box policies, which are production-limiting, are also exempt from the AMS limit.
* The de minimis exemption allows for certain support to be excluded from the AMS calculation if it is below 5% of the value of total annual production or a specific commodity's value.
* The U.S. has never exceeded its AMS limit, with the closest approach being in 2000, when the notified total AMS was $16.8 billion.
* The WTO's Agreement on Agriculture (AoA) categorizes and restricts domestic support programs based on their potential to distort markets, with amber box programs subject to strict spending limits.
* The Agreement on Subsidies and Countervailing Measures (SCM) evaluates the market distortion of domestic support programs, potentially leading to challenges if they result in significant adverse effects on other WTO members.

• The Federal Supplemental Educational Opportunity Grant (FSEOG), Federal Work-Study (FWS), and Federal Perkins Loan programs are collectively referred to as the "campus-based" programs under Title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965.

• These programs are administered directly by institutions of higher education (IHEs) and provide aid to students based on institutional-specific award criteria.

• The campus-based programs' authorizations of appropriations expired at the end of FY2015, but funding for FSEOG and FWS has continued through annual appropriation bills, while Perkins Loans were amended and extended through FY2017.

• The campus-based programs are among the oldest federal financial aid programs, designed to increase access to higher education for students demonstrating financial need.

• The programs' allocation procedures favor long-term participants over new participants, with base guarantees based on prior-year participation.

• Institutions can transfer up to 25% of their Perkins Loan allocation to FSEOG and/or FWS programs, and up to 25% of their FWS allocation to FSEOG and/or Perkins Loans.

• The ACA allows institutions to cover administrative costs of the programs, calculated as a percentage of total campus-based expenditures.

• Participation in the campus-based programs has declined over the past decade, with an uptick in AY2016-2017.

• The programs serve a relatively small proportion of students compared to other federal aid programs, with 10% of undergraduates receiving campus-based aid in AY2011-2012.

• The President's FY2018 budget proposes to eliminate the FSEOG program, allow the Perkins Loan program to wind down, and decrease funding for the FWS program.

• Issues related to the campus-based programs during HEA reauthorization may include their unique purpose, the formula for allocating funds, and specific program issues like targeting and community service requirements.

* The report describes 11 states with active alert systems for missing adults, targeting vulnerable populations due to age, cognitive or physical disabilities, or mental health conditions. These systems are similar to AMBER Alerts but focus on adults at risk of going missing.
* States vary in how they administer and activate alerts, with some having statewide agencies responsible for activation and others involving local law enforcement. Coordination with AMBER Alert systems is common, but dissemination methods differ.
* The federal government has played a role in preventing and assisting in the recovery of missing adults, with programs like the Missing Alzheimer's Disease Patient Alert grant and the Kristen's Act grant. Legislation has been proposed to reauthorize and expand these efforts, including establishing a national Silver Alert communications network.

* The report analyzes annual appropriations for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for FY2017, comparing the enacted FY2016 appropriations, the Obama Administration's FY2017 budget request, the Trump Administration's requests for additional funding, and the appropriations measures developed in response.
* The report provides a detailed breakdown of the FY2017 DHS appropriations, including comparisons of the Obama and Trump Administration requests, and the enacted amounts, for each component and title of the appropriations bill. It also discusses the implementation of a common appropriations structure (CAS) for DHS and the role of general provisions in the bill.

• The September 11 attacks highlighted the vulnerability of the US water supply and quality infrastructure to terrorist attacks, including physical disruption, bioterrorism, chemical contamination, and cyber attacks.

• Water infrastructure systems are highly interconnected with other critical infrastructure like electric power and transportation, making their security a concern.

• These systems include surface and groundwater sources, dams, reservoirs, aqueducts, pipes, treatment facilities, and wastewater collection and treatment facilities.

• The federal government has built hundreds of water projects, primarily for irrigation development and flood control, but is responsible for only about 5% of the dams that could cause significant loss of life or property damage.

• Following the 9/11 attacks, federal dam operators increased security measures, and all Corps facilities were temporarily closed to visitors.

• EPA, in partnership with water utility associations, has developed tools and guidance for vulnerability assessments and security improvements.

• Research has been ongoing to address gaps in threat/vulnerability risk assessments, identification of biological and chemical agents, and information assurance techniques.

• Wastewater treatment facilities have vulnerabilities, including access to large underground sewers and potential for chemical releases.

• EPA has provided grants for vulnerability assessments and training, and utilities have developed security guidance documents.

• The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) coordinates with EPA to provide security information and guidance to water utilities.

• Congress has provided funding for security-related programs and activities, and has considered legislation to address water security issues.

• The debate continues on how to pay for security improvements, with some utilities seeking federal reimbursement for increased costs.

• The Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Improvement Act of 2006 (Perkins IV) reauthorizes and amends the Perkins Act, providing funding for vocational and technical education through FY2012.

• Perkins IV strengthens and changes accountability requirements, including establishing separate core indicators of performance for secondary and postsecondary levels, linking these to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act (ESEA), and requiring eligible recipients to accept state-adjusted levels of performance or negotiate their own.

• The act modifies funding formulas, with adjustments for "additional funds" above the FY2006 funding level, and changes the state allotment formula when such funds are available.

• Perkins IV includes changes to state and local plans, with requirements for measures of academic and technical skill attainment, articulation agreements, and professional development focused on integrating academic content and CTE.

• The tech-prep program is expanded, requiring tech-prep programs to align with ESEA core academic subjects, integrate academic and CTE instruction, and provide career guidance and academic counseling.

* The federal estate, gift, and generation-skipping transfer taxes are explained in this report, focusing on their application in 2014. The estate and gift taxes were phased out over a 10-year period by the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001, with the generation-skipping transfer tax being temporarily reinstated in 2010 with lower rates and larger exemptions.
* The unified estate and gift tax system requires the combination of a decedent's lifetime taxable gifts and taxable estate, with the tax rate schedule applied to this total. Available credits, including the unified transfer tax credit, reduce the actual estate tax liability.
* The gross estate of a decedent includes all property, real or personal, tangible or intangible, owned by the decedent at death, as well as certain interests transferred prior to death. This can also include lifetime gifts over which the decedent retained a life interest or power to alter the property's beneficial enjoyment.
* The taxable estate is determined by reducing the gross estate with allowable deductions, such as funeral expenses, administration costs, debts, charitable bequests, and state death taxes. The unified transfer tax credit, which is available against both lifetime gift and estate taxes, is a key deduction.
* The federal gift tax applies to gratuitous transfers of property during life, with the tax liability based on the fair market value of the gift, less exclusions like the annual per donee exclusion, gift tax marital deduction, and gift tax charitable deduction. The gift tax follows the same progressive rates as the estate tax, with the computation involving the donor's lifetime taxable gifts and the application of the unified transfer tax credit.

* The Border and Transportation Security (BTS) function aims to protect the American people from terrorists and their instruments of destruction.
* The federal government has implemented multiple programs and policies to achieve enhanced border and transportation security.
* The three reports in this series aim to provide an understanding of the complex problems in seeking enhanced security, suggest a framework for existing programs and policies, and explore possible new directions and policy options.
* The continuum of activities to provide homeland security starts with preventive efforts outside the country and progresses through more localized measures, ending with emergency preparedness and response.
* Border management is a complex task, and current programs and policies to strengthen the border and facilitate the flow of legitimate people and things can seem overwhelming.
* Congressional concern with terrorism and border security was manifested early, following a series of terrorist attacks beginning in the 1990s.
* The Homeland Security Act of 2002 consolidated many federal agencies responsible for border and transportation security into a single department, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS).
* The DHS is the primary federal agency responsible for securing the border, with the Customs and Border Protection (CBP) component tasked with securing the borders, territorial waters, terminals, waterways, and air, land, and sea transportation systems of the United States.
* The activities discussed in the report are divided into categories of how they provide BTS, further divided into people and goods security-related programs.
* The report traces the development of selected programs and policies designed to achieve higher levels of border and transportation security, presenting them in a framework that facilitates a better understanding of current approaches and some possible new directions.

* Cabo Verde, a small island nation off the coast of Senegal, has historical ties to the United States and is considered an important partner in West Africa.
* The country's strategic location has made it a transshipment point for Latin American cocaine bound for Europe and a key refueling stop for transatlantic flights.
* U.S.-Cabo Verdean cooperation focuses on counternarcotics efforts, military professionalization, and development projects supported by the Millennium Challenge Corporation.
* Cabo Verde is eligible for tariff preferences under the African Growth and Opportunity Act (AGOA), though its use of these benefits is minimal.
* Congressional activity typically involves high-level meetings with Cabo Verdean officials during periodic delegations.
* The country's political system takes into account its large expatriate population, whose remittances are a key source of investment and hard currency.
* Cabo Verde transitioned to democracy in 1991, with the African Party for the Independence of Cabo Verde (PAICV) and the Movement for Democracy (MPD) dominating politics.
* The MPD, which won the 2016 parliamentary elections, prioritizes economic expansion, job growth, infrastructure, and crime reduction.
* Cabo Verde faces challenges including rule of law, human rights, and economic dependence on Europe, which has contributed to sluggish growth.
* The country is diversifying its aid and trade partnerships, seeking stronger relationships with countries like China, Brazil, and Angola.

• The return of security cooperation between the United States and New Zealand to a high level has forged a new security partnership between the two countries, focusing on shared democratic values and common interests. This partnership has been bolstered by recent developments, including the lifting of a ban on New Zealand naval ship visits to U.S. ports and increased participation in joint military exercises and regional security initiatives.

• The evolving national identity of New Zealand, influenced by its changing demographic composition, has shifted its foreign policy orientation towards greater engagement in the Asia Pacific region. This includes a focus on strengthening its leadership role in the South Pacific, where New Zealand sees itself as a key player in promoting security, stability, and prosperity. The country's strategic guidance and historical ties with the region underscore its commitment to being an active participant in its near region, while also diversifying its economic interests through engagement with Asia and regional economic architectures.

• The U.S. Constitution establishes two methods for Presidents to appoint officers of the United States: with the advice and consent of the Senate or during the recess of the Senate.
• These provisions have historically led to political tension between Presidents and Congresses.
• President Obama faced challenges in obtaining Senate confirmation for nominations to the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection (CFPB) and the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB).
• On January 4, 2012, President Obama made recess appointments to these positions, leading to legal challenges.
• A court would first consider the standing of the plaintiffs to challenge the appointments.
• Private individuals, businesses, or associations may have standing if they have been impacted by actions taken by the CFPB or NLRB after the appointments.
• Congressional plaintiffs, such as individual Members or the Senate as a whole, may also have standing if their injury amounts to "vote nullification."
• The political question doctrine may prevent a court from reviewing the case if the issues are considered inappropriate for judicial resolution.
• The court may consider whether pro forma sessions of the Senate interrupt an intrasession recess for the purpose of the Recess Appointments Clause.
• The length of a recess required for a President to make a recess appointment is not explicitly defined in the Constitution.
• A court may consider historical precedent or descriptive criteria to define a "Recess" for purposes of the Clause.
• The use of pro forma sessions by the Senate may raise separation of powers concerns if they prevent a President from making recess appointments.
• Assuming the constitutionality of the appointment of Richard Cordray, questions remain about the impact of the President's recess appointment on Cordray's and the Secretary's authorities.
• A court could interpret section 1066 of the Consumer Financial Protection Act to grant Cordray all authorities or limit the Secretary's transferred powers until a Senate-confirmed Director is appointed.
• The interpretation of section 1066 could impact the constitutional authority of the President to make recess appointments if it restricts the powers of a recess appointee.
• A constitutional analysis would consider whether the interpretation raises separation of powers concerns or violates the President's constitutional authority.
• The Supreme Court has generally deferred to the President's role in the appointment process, suggesting a presumption of constitutionality for his actions under the Recess Appointments Clause.

* The Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) sets forth procedures for the exclusion and removal of non-U.S. nationals (aliens) who do not meet specified criteria regarding their entry or presence within the United States. Typically, aliens within the U.S. may not be removed without due process.
* Congress has broad authority over the admission of aliens seeking to enter the U.S. The Supreme Court has held that the government may exclude an alien seeking entry without affording him traditional due process protections, instead providing only those procedural protections that Congress expressly authorized.
* Section 235(b)(1) of the INA provides for the expedited removal of arriving aliens who do not have valid entry documents or have attempted to gain admission through fraud or misrepresentation. Under this streamlined removal procedure, aliens may be summarily removed without a hearing or further review.
* Aliens subject to expedited removal may seek review of an asylum claim before removal. If the review determines the claim is credible, the alien will be placed in formal removal proceedings where he can pursue asylum and related protections. Additionally, aliens may seek administrative review of claims that they are U.S. citizens, lawful permanent residents, admitted refugees, or asylees. Unaccompanied alien children are not subject to expedited removal.

* The principle of "one person, one vote" requires congressional districts to contain approximately the same population.
* The Supreme Court has allowed for some deviation from precise equality, but it must be justified by legitimate state objectives.
* Partisanship can justify small differences in population between districts, but it must not be the predominant factor.
* The total population, not eligible voters, should be counted for the purposes of achieving equality among districts.
* The creation of majority-minority districts may be required under the Voting Rights Act to avoid racial vote dilution.
* There are constitutional limits on the creation of minority-majority districts, requiring that the minority group constitute more than 50% of the voting population.
* Congressional redistricting plans must conform with standards of equal protection under the Fourteenth Amendment.
* The Supreme Court has clarified that compliance with the Voting Rights Act does not require maintaining a specific numerical percentage of minority voters in majority-minority districts.
* The Elections Clause permits states to use the initiative process to create independent commissions for congressional redistricting.
* Legislation in the 114th Congress aims to establish additional statutory requirements and standards for congressional redistricting.

* The past decade has seen substantial debate and proposals related to fire protection programs and funding, prompted by severe fire seasons.
* President Clinton proposed the National Fire Plan in 2000, which Congress largely enacted, to increase funding for protecting federal, state, and private lands.
* President Bush proposed the Healthy Forests Initiative in 2002 to expedite fuel reduction on federal lands, leading to the Healthy Forests Restoration Act of 2003.
* In 2009, the Federal Land Assistance, Management, and Enhancement (FLAME) Act was enacted to insulate other agency programs from high wildfire suppression costs.
* Wildfire funding has remained high since 2000, constituting a substantial portion of land management agency budgets.
* Severe fire seasons seem to have become more common since 2000, with total wildfire funding reaching a record high of $4.46 billion in FY2008.
* The FS and DOI use three fire appropriation accounts to fund most federal fire programs, with different activities included in each.
* Funding for protecting federal lands differs from funding for non-federal lands, with the latter giving states and other entities substantial discretion on how funds are used.
* The FLAME Act established FLAME Wildfire Suppression Reserve Accounts for the FS and DOI to fund routine wildfire suppression and protection efforts if other accounts are depleted.
* Fuel reduction funding has more than tripled since FY2001, but has declined in recent years, and funding for assistance programs for protecting non-federal lands has also fluctuated.
* Four key issues related to wildfire funding have arisen in recent years: high costs of wildfire management, fuel reduction efforts, federal role in fire protection of non-federal lands, and post-fire rehabilitation.

* About 27.5% of state and local government employees in the U.S. are not covered by Social Security.
* Coverage rates vary significantly across states, with some having over 95% covered and others under 5%.
* Social Security coverage for state and local employees is voluntary and can be extended through "Section 218 Agreements."
* Coverage is extended to groups of positions, not individuals, and varies greatly from state to state.
* Mandatory Social Security coverage for newly hired state and local government employees has been recommended by deficit reduction groups.
* Implementing mandatory coverage is projected to have a net positive effect on the Social Security Trust Funds.
* Mandatory coverage could simplify retirement planning and benefit coordination for workers with state and local government positions.
* It could result in better benefit protections through Social Security's dependents' and survivors' benefits.
* However, opponents argue it may not necessarily result in better benefit protections and could impose administrative burdens.
* Non-covered state and local government workers are not currently contributing to Social Security's poverty reduction and ongoing costs.
* Mandatory coverage is seen by some as fair, as most non-covered workers will qualify for Social Security benefits under current law.

* TAA provides federal assistance to workers who lose their jobs due to foreign competition, offering funding for training, reemployment services, and income support.
* Workers over 50 may qualify for the Reemployment Trade Adjustment Assistance (RTAA) wage supplement program.
* TAA was reauthorized by the Trade Adjustment Assistance Reauthorization Act of 2015 (TAARA), effective through June 30, 2021.
* The program aims to assist workers affected by reduced trade barriers and increased trade, with benefits potentially limited to those affected by declines in international trade.
* TAA is jointly administered by the U.S. Department of Labor and state agencies, funded by mandatory appropriations, and subject to sequestration.
* To obtain benefits, a group of workers must petition the Department of Labor to establish foreign trade's role in their job loss, followed by individual applications for state-administered benefits.
